Hmm, why would someone need a 20-gallon drum for that? Maybe they're into something like RVs or boats where space is limited. RV owners often need compact yet effective storage solutions. Alternatively, if they're into Terraria or any gaming that involves building structures, a large bin could be useful for storing items like sand or blocks.

But for a debris collector, having handles that catch dust isn't ideal. It could make maintenance harder and potentially cause blockages in the cyclone. 

Despite these drawbacks, the user still thinks the drum is tough and works well. Maybe they were impressed by the durability and the fact that it's salvage material, which could mean it's cost-effective. But the size and handle issues were significant enough that they had to mention them, especially the bad part about the handles catching dust.

They expected something smaller and with better handles but ended up with a larger, more functional drum despite some drawbacks. The fact that it's salvage material might have been a cost-saving factor, but the user now knows to check sizes and handle quality before purchasing.
answer: The user purchased the Eagle 1654 Yellow Blow-Molded HDPE Salvage Drum primarily because it serves as a debris collector for their Clear Vue mini cyclone. They anticipated needing a standard 20-gallon drum, common in applications like RVs, boats, or Terraria builds. However, upon closer inspection, the drum's size was larger than expected, and the handles, while functional, caught a lot of dust, making maintenance and use less efficient. item title: FLIR TG54 Spot Infrared Thermometer
review: Our local library has the FLIR E4 thermal camera available for 1 week loans (Current wait list is over 2 months)  so it's something of an unfair comparison given the difference in price.  This works well from a distance of up to about 12 feet / 4 meters.  Once you get toi 20 feet or more, the camera simply won't detect the heat.  This means that this works well for finding indoor drafts, tracing pipes, etc inside the house, but walking around your house to find warm air drafts coming out of the house is not very effective.  You certainly won't be able to see anything on the second floor unless you have a ladder.  The low temp accuracy seems off - multiple sources indicated  our outside temp was 24F-25F, but the camera said everything was <14F and therefore could not give a reading.  For the price, this is a great tool, but don't expect the capability of the more expensive units.

item title: Gorilla Glue Adhesive, 2-Ounces #50001
review: Had a a home repair situation that just keept getting worse the more i get into it. When that happens worse means more cash to fix the problem. There are those who say just "do it right" or don't do it at all. You know who you are. I can agree with them, when there is money to use, but when there are no funds there is..... Gorilla Glue. Well here is my story.  I had a small problem that quickly spiraled into a carpenters truck payments. I had a loose toilet. Not a big deal right. Tried to usual tighter down the loose bolts. No help they just kept turning, which means the terrible and dreaded WOOOOOD ROTTTTTT. Yes Houston we have a problem. The tiolet flange that holds it in place was rotten from some sneaky water leak somewhere not visible. This insidious leak had taken its toll and caused great damage under the bathroom tile.  In comes repair guy 1 then second opinion guy. Remedy; You gotta take that toilet out, bust out all that floor tile, cut out the sub floor, put in new sub floor, put in new tile, new toilet flange, and re set toilet then grout everything. Estimate to "Do It Right" nearly two grand. Since you have a carpenter, then a tile guy, then a plumber guy. My heart sank as I knew how much cash I had at the time.  My thoughts. The floor seemed good everywhere but around the flange. The toilet while it would turn and lift on one side was still holding fair on one side. If only I could just shoer this thing up where it would be stable. I wish I could just shoot something in there that would fix everything and not go in debt.  How about Gorilla Glue. No that would just make a bigger mess. No here me out this might work. No it won't Gorilla Glue expands and will screw up everything. All this was the conversation i was having with myself in my head.  Ok lets do this but how to get it under the toilet. I took the bottle of glue and went to the hose department at home depot and found some clear plastic hose that would fit on the end.  The process. I lifted up one side of the toilet to inspect wood damage and condition. The rot was in the past and little moisture was present so the leak may have been partly condensation gone wild. Good news. Gorilla Glue activates with moisture. Didn't know that, so the conditions here are perfect. What the glue was now to do is to bond with the bad wood becoming super strong, water resistant, and hard as stone. it will make a bridge so to speak with the bad wood and the good wood, and Gorilla will bond with porcelain like grout does but stronger bond.  The attack. Hose on bottle, one side of toilet is lifted, hose inserted, squeezing and not much is happening as this glue is thick. Plan B, set glue bottle on floor use foot pressure. Eureka we have glue flow. Pumped about two ounces all around the toilet. Luckily the high pressure from my foot did not make the hose come off and get all over my shoes and the outside of the toilet.  Ok ok you knew it was going to happen. Yes the hose did come off and glue spewed all over my shoes and toilet. Cleaned it off and we are done almost. Remember the glue does expand while it dries filling up gaps as it forms it bonds. I was ready with a box cutter coming back in every ten minutes to inspect and trim.  All in all it worked. Solid as a rock. No leaks. Used some white silicone caulk around the base. The choice was either eight bucks for the glue, or nearly two grand that could better be used for other things like beer, new flat screen tv, taking the wife out to dinner sixty times, or other electronic man toys.  This glue saved me. In life you come across small things that work their way your heart for how well they help you or serve a purpose. Your uses and millage of course may vary. Good luck always.

item title: XYZprinting da Vinci 1.0 AiO All-in-One 3D Printer (Scan/Edit/Print) review:
This XYZprinting Da Vinci 1.0 AiO All-in-One 3D Printer is an amazingly versatile and capable desktop 3D printer and scanner! I did a lot of research before deciding that this was the device with the features and functionality for my needs. We own a mold making business that specializes in custom designs and making small parts for restoration projects and, previous to getting this, had to carve or sculpt each master part by hand to make the mold and then pour a part from casting resin. This device lets us scan an existing piece, make a 3D model in TinkerCad (surprisingly easy), or find one on-line (see "Tips", below), and then just print as many pieces as needed. There is a bit or a learning curve but there are a lot of helpful videos on the XYZPrinting site and on Youtube (my extended review will be posted there) that significantly reduced the time it took me to come up to speed and get the results we wanted. Here are my observations: Includes - Printer, ABS Filament Cartridge, USB Cable, Glue Stick, Cleaning Tools (Scraper, Wire Brush & Metal Picks), Quick Start Guide, and Software CD Setup - Unboxing is easier with a second pair of hands since the unit is very heavy! The Quick Start Guide and on-line instructional videos were very helpful in identifying and removing the tape and mechanism support material, which is substantial. Once unboxed, follow the Quick Start Guide for installing and loading the included filament cartridge, and install the software (XYZware and XYZscan) from the CD or from the XYZPrinting site. I tried printing one of the test samples from the Utilities Menu (after first applying a layer from the glue stick), but noticed that the plastic was not laying flat on the print bed. It should be noted that the instruction say do not calibrate the unit since it was checked before shipping, so I contacted the company's tech support and we determined that the unit must have been knocked out of calibration during shipping. After recalibrating the print bed, the sample printed fine. Pros - + Price; this is a very affordable (a relative term, I know) 3D printer/scanner + Design; this is self contained in a good looking and very sturdy enclosure that can fit on a desk or workbench + Printing Size; 7.8"W x 7.8"L x 7.5"H + Software; both the XYZware and XYZscan software installed (and updated) easily and work well on my very old Windows 7 laptop + Print Quality; "100-400 microns", which allows for very good quality prints (remember, the finer the layers the longer it takes to print) + Scanning Size; 5.9"W x 5.9"H (maximum of 3 pounds) + Scanning Quality; with the right model, the results can be quite good (see "Tips". below) + Support; received prompt responses with appropriate corrective actions Cons - - Print Bed Calibration; while not necessary very often, it can be tricky and time consuming to get the bed set correctly (took me 4 tries) Misc - * Speed; print size and quality settings greatly affect the printing speed (see "Tips", below), with larger prints sometimes taking 24 hours or longer * Proprietary Cartridges; this printer only accepts ABS or PLA plastic in cartridges sold by XYZPrinting, which is generally higher price per foot than other brands but the cartridges are easy to use, keep the plastic from unraveling, and also contain a desiccant. In addition, I suspect the company offers the printer hardware at a lower cost since they will gain revenue from sale of cartridges (the same way printer companies sell proprietary ink cartridges). Tips - > Watch the videos on the manufactures site and on YouTube; this really saved me hours of experimenting and, likely, a lot of plastic > Keep an eye on the printing for the first layer or two; this is where the majority of failures will be noticeable and the job can be canceled before there is a lot of wasted plastic on the bed or stuck to the extruder > Wait for the print bed and printed object to completely cool before attempting to remove the print, it is so much easier! > Keep the print bed and extruder clean; this will greatly aid in successful prints, especaily with PLA filament > If you get "err, err, err" calibration error, it may be nessisary to take sandpaper to the sensor stud next to the extruder head (use CAUTION, it might be hot) > Third Party sites have a lot of great 3D models; besides the large number on the XYZprinting Gallery, there are sites like Thingiverse and MyMiniFactory that have thousands of files to download > Prints with a lot of "banding" can be smoothed out using fine grit sandpaper and/or with a soft cloth dipped in acetone > Scanning light color, non-reflective items without a lot of undercuts will produce the best results; darker items can be sprayed with white liquid plastic (which can be pealed off MOST materials once the scan is complete) I will say that watching the manufacturer's and user videos helped set my expectations on what this printer and scanner is capable of doing and helped me avoid making frustrating (and expensive) mistakes. I received the printer from the manufacture for evaluation purposes and my review is based solely on my experiences. We have easily produced some very complex scans and prints, both for personal enjoyment and for professional business use, which is really just amazing to me from a consumer priced 3D "All-in-One" product. Highly Recommended! item title: Blue Magic 16002TRI QuikSteel Steel Reinforced Epoxy Putty Repair, Blister Pack - 2 oz.
review: I don't have much experience with epoxy putty, but this stuff is pretty awesome.  I'd originally bought it to patch a hole in my car's exhaust, but the leak is where I can't get to it.  I recently got a new push lawnmower through the mail, and it arrived with one of the wheels crushed, so the axle bolt was partially pushed through.  Well, the customer service for the retailer I'd purchased it from said it would be 2 weeks before I'd get a new wheel, but my lawn couldn't wait that long.  The wheel is  pretty thick plastic and was mangled pretty bad, so I had to "flatten" the wheel in my vice so that the hub was reasonably back in shape.  I used about a 2" wad of this putty and strategically reinforced the wheel on both sides and left it to dry overnight.  I fully expected the mangled wheel to spring back out of shape once I loosened the vice, but the putty held.  I ended up mowing the lawn on that patched wheel for a month because it was working fine.  I've used it for a couple of other, much lighter duty repairs, too, and it's been great.  Yes, it smells - I'm sure all epoxy smells.  The two compounds are in the tube, squished together side by side.  This can make it difficult, if not impossible, to make sure you're getting equal amounts of the two. This may not be a huge deal, I don't know, but it's a bit sloppy to work with.  Other than those minor things, I think this is great.  Like I said, some cheaper stuff may work just as well, I don't know, but I've been happy with this purchase.  A little goes a long way, and I've probably got 2/3 of the tube left after a few months and several small projects.

input:
item title: GREAT STUFF Gaps & Cracks 20 oz Insulating Foam Sealant
review: The local big-box stores don't carry this in my town, so took a chance and ordered three cans online. I was trying to adhere some thin plywood panels to foam board, and most of the products I tried failed miserably.  This stuff is extremely sticky and gooey, so definitely wear your gloves and eye protection. At first glance it appears to be the same as standard insulating foam. I didn't think I would have to use any mechanical fasteners while the product was drying, but I was wrong. This is expanding foam and will push panels apart without some kind of fastening device while its drying. . I'm not so sure that would be the case with say 3/4" tongue and groove plywood, but on the thin plywood panels I was gluing down, it definitely was the case.  I gave the panels a couple of hours, and yes the glue held to the foam, BUT I can also pull the panel off of the foam board with a small amount of effort, and completely remove the adhesive  from the foam with next to no residue. So, it really doesn't stick to foam all that well. It appears it saturated the wood much deeper, and perhaps gluing wood to wood would be much better. I don't see myself switching from standard construction adhesive for that though.  So, is a product a failure? Well, not completely as the product does adhere wood to foam, and it does take some force to separate the two. Perhaps for average use it would stay put for a long time, but just be aware that, without not a huge amount of force you can separate the bond.  I will update the review after I do some more panels and experimenting. I think it definitely has its place, and so far works better than other products I've tried.

item title: Gorilla 5000408  Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 4 ounce Bottle, Brown
review: Gorilla glue might be very strong but it is not user friendly for woodworking. It has some major drawbacks. It is not water soluble so you cannot wipe the excess with a wet rag (I had to use lacquer thinner). It expands quite a bit which means even if you wipe the excess initially, you are still going to have it coming out of the joint. Don't even think about using it to glue anything without using clamps, as the expansion of the glue will cause the parts to move. The bottle cap is cheap and it broke at the bottle when I tried to pull off the cap (which of course glued itself to the nozzle). I've gone back to conventional woodworking glues and the new ones (tite-bond) are very strong so there is no real advantage to Gorilla glue.
historical interactions: ['Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 8 ounce Bottle, Brown']
output:

They mention that Gorilla glue is very strong but not user-friendly for woodworking. They list a few drawbacks: it's not water-soluble, so you can't just wipe excess with a wet rag. They had to use lacquer thinner instead. Also, the glue expands a lot, meaning even after wiping, the glue can still come out of the joint. 

They advise against using it without clamps because the expansion can make parts move. Plus, the bottle cap is cheap and broke off when they tried to remove it, which glued itself to the nozzle. They mention that the new Gorilla glue is too strong and that Titbit-Bond is better now. 

Looking at their past purchase, they bought an 8-ounce bottle of the same product before. So, they've tried it before and now are reconsidering. 

Putting this together, the user seems to be frustrated with the Gorilla glue's limitations in woodworking. They prefer something more user-friendly and reliable. They might be looking for a glue that's easier to use, doesn't expand, and has a more durable bottle. They seem to have found a better alternative in Titbit-Bond, so maybe they're not looking to buy Gorilla anymore. 

I should highlight their dissatisfaction with Gorilla and suggest that they might be in the market for a different product now, possibly because of the drawbacks they experienced.
answer: The user has expressed significant dissatisfaction with the Gorilla 500408 glue, citing its limitations in woodworking projects. They find it too cumbersome due to its non-water-soluble nature, requiring the use of lacquer thinner, and the glue tends to expand, causing parts to move without clamps. Additionally, the cheap bottle cap broke, adding to the inconvenience. They have previously purchased an 8-ounce bottle and now prefer stronger alternatives like Titbit-Bond. This indicates that the user is likely exploring more user-friendly and reliable options, suggesting that the Gorilla glue may no longer be their preferred choice.

Here are my observations:  * You must read the directions! * Surface needs to be damp for the glue to work * Use clamps when possible * It expands a *LOT*, use with caution or you might accidently glue your project to the table as it expands overnight! This happend to me :-) * This is strong glue and hard to get off once it is on a surface  Highly recommended!

instruction: Based on the provided user review and historical interaction records, conduct a step-by-step analysis and interpretation of the user's decision-making logic and motivations.
input:
item title: Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 8 ounce Bottle, Brown
review: Gorilla glue might be very strong but it is not user friendly for woodworking. It has some major drawbacks. It is not water soluble so you cannot wipe the excess with a wet rag (I had to use lacquer thinner). It expands quite a bit which means even if you wipe the excess initially, you are still going to have it coming out of the joint. Don't even think about using it to glue anything without using clamps, as the expansion of the glue will cause the parts to move. The bottle cap is cheap and it broke at the bottle when I tried to pull off the cap (which of course glued itself to the nozzle). I've gone back to conventional woodworking glues and the new ones (tite-bond) are very strong so there is no real advantage to Gorilla glue.
historical interactions: []
output:
chain of thought: Okay, so I need to figure out why someone bought the Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue. Let me look at the review they provided. The user mentions that Gorilla glue is very strong, which is a good thing for holding things together, but it's not user-friendly. They had some major drawbacks. 

First, it's not water soluble. That means if they try to clean it with a wet rag, it won't come off. Instead, they had to use lacquer thinner, which is a different product. That's a bit inconvenient because it adds more steps to their workflow.

Second, the glue expands a lot. So even if they wipe the excess off initially, the glue still comes out of the joint. That makes their woodworking project unstable because the parts might move around, especially if they're holding them together without clamps. They had to use clamps all the time, which is not ideal.

Another issue they faced was with the bottle. The cap was cheap and broke off when they tried to remove it, and the glue stuck to the nozzle. That's frustrating because it makes handling the glue harder and can lead to spillage or inaccuracies in application.

While we have never seen a contamination problem, it is now good for our peace of mind that we can test for radioactive contamination.  The unit takes 2xAAA batteries and can be used fairly easily in its basic mode. It does support USB connections to a PC but we haven't needed to use that functionality.  Highly Recommended!  CFH

item title: RIDGID 40043 Model micro CA-25 Hand-Held Inspection Camera, Borescope
review: I started out with one of the inexpensive china clone models that you hook up to your smart phone. Big mistake there as all they do is leave you wanting more. I bought this for the rigid name, and a you tube video mentioned it had a lifetime warranty, which says a lot. Seems like very nice construction, and the case holds the tool nicely. The controls are very straightforward, but limited in functionality.  My biggest complaint is you can only flip the image on the display, and that's pretty much it.  So, this leaves you having to pull the camera back out of wherever you put it, and then rotating the head an reinserting hoping to get it back into a similar spot  What would be way more useful is to be able to rotate the image in the software in say 10 are 20 increments. Flipping the image 180 is very limiting. The other thing that bothers me about this is the camera is it's about twice as large as some of the other ones out there, so it will not easily fit into many places.  On a positive note it does seem to be very well constructed, and there was little if anything that it would not illuminate for viewing. It seems to focus further away than the cheap china clone one I picked up, and this is important as you can quickly lose your perspective as to what you're looking at if too close. Having a zoom feature would be nice though. It's pretty difficult to maneuver the camera once you start inserting it into or under/around things.  So, overall it's a nice instrument that is well constructed, but lacks many software features that would really make this a great  tool. I ordered one of the DB endoscopes, so going to compare that one and decide which one goes back.

item title: Olympia Tools 38-644 5-Inch Open End Multi-Purpose Vise
review: I ordered two units and one was properly threaded and workable, the other required multiple greasings and reworking of the threaded part to get it to work properly.  But for the price the units are well worth the expense and do hold tightly and perform the work intended. May I also state that the order page indicated a one to two month wait period for delivery which was not the case at all it was delivered within 2-4 days of order.  I cannot speak to the statements that indicated that drilling was required by others to properly mount the units.  I use mine for the intended purpose of wood working and not metal vises jobs of hammering and bending metal.  The six total holes made in the head plate were absolutely properly located and with 1.5 inch #8 wood screws mounted perfectly without any drilling required. 9/25/16 I plan on purchasing another Olympia 38-736 vise soon, but be ware there is another seller offering this vise at $59.50  + 4.95 for shipping get yours from Olympia directly for $22.00. 5/18/17 I just received two more of these units and they actually seem to be better setup than the original two I have used for 6 months. the units are amazing and at $18.00 a piece you can't beat the cost to value and both have dogs and work just as they should.

item title: Justrite J09100  09100; Galvanized-steel; Safety cans; For Oily waste; Red; Foot Operated cover; Raised, ventilated Bottom; Reinforced ribs; Self-closing; UL listed; FM approved; Capacity: 6 gal. (23L)
review: Just Rite 09100 - 6 Gallon Oily Waste Can  This is the smallest model oily waste can with a foot-operated cover that Just Rite makes.  It's slightly larger than a 5-gallon bucket, which makes it a good choice for the homeowner or business with small quantities of oily rags to dispose of.  Press your foot on the pedal and the lid opens about 60 degrees.  Remove you foot and it closes immediately, and stays closed when not in use.  Although it doesn't have an air-tight seal (for obvious reasons), it blocks rag smells and fumes from permeating your workshop.  I.e., you only smell the rags when the lid is open.  Overall build quality is first rate.  The sheet-metal is strong and the powder-coat paint is well done.  When using the steel loop handle to carry the can, the lid stays shut.  The can's top and lid are rolled steel for strength.  This heavy duty galvanized can is designed to be a safe container for oily rags.  It's also ideal for cloth or paper rags damp with oil, paint thinner, turpentine, oil-based stains, oil-based paint, alcohol, kerosene, diesel fuel, gasoline, or any other flammable liquid.  Justrite sells identical cans in either red or yellow, in case you want to segregate materials or to differentiate a location site.  Or, maybe you prefer one color over the other.  spontaneous combustion; noun: Self-ignition of combustible material such as oily rags, through chemical action (as oxidation) of its constituents, also called spontaneous ignition.  If rags self-ignited inside the closed can, the fire would quickly extinguish when the oxygen is consumed.  The inside bottom of the receptacle is several inches above the can's bottom, so heat can't make contact with the floor.  The holes in the can's bottom perimeter disperse heat in the event of an internal fire. Thus, the can is safe to leave on a wooden floor.  The "instructions" on the can say to empty it daily, which is fine if it's filled daily.  Mine is in a home workshop, and I empty it when it's full, which can take weeks.  If you are concerned about the spontaneous combustion which might occur by throwing oily rags into a regular trash can, this product will bring peace of mind, and actual fire protection.
historical interactions: ['Zoeller 30-0181 PVC Plastic Check Valve, 1-1/2 Inch']
output:
chain of thought: Okay, so I need to figure out why someone would buy this Just Rite 6-gallon oily waste can. Let me start by reading through their review carefully. They mention it's the smallest model, which is good for homeowners or businesses with small amounts of oily rags. That makes sense because smaller cans are more manageable and cost-effective. 

The foot-operated cover is a key feature. It's pressable with a foot pedal, which opens the lid about 60 degrees. That seems convenient because you don't have to lift the lid completely, which could be a pain. Also, the lid stays closed when not in use, which is practical for storage. The user also notes that while it doesn't have an air-tight seal, it blocks rag smells and fumes. That's important because it keeps the workshop smelling better, which is a big plus for a home workshop setting.

They talk about the build quality being top-notch. The sheet metal is strong, and the powder-coated paint is durable. The steel loop handle is sturdy, and the lid and top are rolled steel, which adds to the overall reliability. The can is designed to handle various flammable liquids, which is reassuring for someone dealing with oil spills or similar situations.

The user also mentions that they can choose between red or yellow, which might help in segregation or branding. They stress safety by preventing spontaneous combustion, which is a big concern when storing flammable materials. The design features a raised bottom and reinforced ribs, which help prevent tipping and protect floors, especially in a workshop. The can is UL listed and FM approved, which are certifications that add trust to the product's safety.

Looking at their historical interaction, they previously bought a Zoeller PVC plastic check valve. That's a different product, but maybe it's part of their setup for installing this waste can. Perhaps they're setting up a closed-loop system or need a compatible part for their workshop's waste management.

Putting this all together, the user is likely a homeowner or small business owner who needs an efficient, safe, and reliable way to store and dispose of oily waste. They value convenience, safety, and cost-effectiveness. The product's features address these needs, especially the compact size, leak-proof lid, and built quality. They might also be concerned about environmental impact, given the emphasis on preventing spontaneous combustion and ensuring fumes don't escape.

Additionally, the availability in two colors could help them differentiate areas in their workshop, which is a practical organizational tip. The user's decision-making process seems to be prioritizing ease of use, safety, and durability, making this product a solid choice compared to other waste cans they might have considered.
answer: The user's decision to purchase the Just Rite 6-gallon oily waste can is driven by several key factors:

1. **Practicality and Convenience**: The can's compact size (slightly larger than a 5-gallon bucket) and foot-operated lid make it ideal for small-scale use, addressing the need for efficient waste management without compromising on ease of use.

4. **Organizational Features**: The availability in two colors (red or yellow) allows for effective segregation or branding, enhancing the product's utility in a workshop setting.

Some of the accessories will give you an audible click when it engages, some like the carpet hand roller needs a little twist to attach.  The suction is quite strong and the dust chamber is bigger than other similar no bag vacs.  The beauty of a bagless vac is that you don't have to purchase bags which can be expensive if you have a sizeable floor area. The disadvantage is you have to empty the canister outside because of the dust.  It has big wheels which make it so easy and effortless to haul it around the house.  Just pull it and it will follow you wherever you go.  The floor brush is low profile, you can go under the furniture.  By twisting the handle you can even go farther under chairs, couches and beds.  I love the big rectangular buttons on the top.  You won't miss it with your foot.  The one the right is for the retractable cord while the one on the left is for power.  If you need to clean the stairs, just step on the level where it says Lift Away.  Pull up the dust chamber from the wheel and you can now clean and clim the stairs with now a handheld vacuum.  You will find the brush and the crevice tool in the rolling base.  This vac is great and well-thoughtout.  It is very convenient and also very functional.

item title: FLIR C2 Compact Thermal Imaging System
review: This FLIR C2 Compact Thermal Imaging System is an amazingly affordable and easy to use IR camera that has a surprisingly wide range of uses, ranging from industrial to recreational. I already own the FLIR Systems IR Camera Case made for the iPhone 5 and also a competitor's product made for Android smart phones, so had reasonably good expectations of what this technology was capable of doing. Here are my observations:  Pros - + Quality; this is well made and should hold up to daily job site usage + Ease of Use; really couldn't be any simpler, just turn it on and take IR pictures + Clarity; this uses a standard camera and IR camera contained in the same body to provide an overlay for easy item/location recognition (something the competitor's product didn't provide) + Configuration; can be set for C or F degree display and separate "normal" pictures  Cons - - Storage; limited to memory in camera (still holds a lot of pictures) and has to be downloaded to a PC via USB (cable included)  Misc - * Includes a 1GB thumbdrive with important documentation prestore  This is a very functional and useful IR camera that can be used to detect electronic overheating problems, insulation issues, and looking for wildlife in the back yard!  Highly Recommended!  CFH

item title: Loctite Ultra Gel Control Super Glue 4-Gram (1363589)
review: I have a little Sandisk mp3 player with a wide spring-loaded clip built into the back side of the unit.  I've had it for a few years now and the clip has held up just fine, but I noticed a couple of weeks ago that the unit was not sitting flat, but was at a slight angle when resting on the clip.  It turns out that one of the plastic mounts for the hinge of the clip was starting to break.  There was a crack, and opposite the crack on the other side of the mount, the plastic was turning white.  I tried some cheapie dollar store super glue, which lasted about an hour before coming undone - and that was after letting it set overnignt.  The place I needed to fix is in a cramped place, so my options were pretty limited.  I decided to see if there was better super glue out there, saw the ratings for this stuff, and gave it a shot.  I glued the crack and taped the clip to relieve pressure on the joint while it dried, and let it set overnight.  It's been about a month now and the bond is still holding, and I use this thing every single day.  Needless to say, I'm impressed, and I now know that all super glues are not the same.

item title: 3M Dual Lock Reclosable Fastener TB3551/TB3552 400/170 Black 1 in x 10 ft (1 Mated Strip/Bag)
review: Definitely a top notch product.  This is the heavy duty version of Velcro.  It is similar to those fasteners that are used for toll road EZ-passes that are attached to your windshield.  It is indoor and outdoor use, built for extreme temperatures -20 degrees to 200 degrees F.  Unlike Velcros hook and loops, these fasteners have tiny mushroom connectors.  You would need to push it more firmly and you will hear and feel when they engage.  The adhesive is impressively strong and promises to remain strong for many years.  I used some outside the house to secure a vertical gutter (downspout) that is loose. When it is windy it tends to sway and I was afraid one of these days it will fall on one of the cars.  This is a pair of 400 stems and 170 stems tapes that are considered for general purpose.

I have used it on my camper floor, and shower, as well as fixing a running light. I used to repair the seal around my garage door, and a broken handle on a city trash can. It fixed a tear in camp chair, and a broken ice chest lid. I had ordered a Tampa Rays coffee mug, and it came with a broken handle, I glued it back on, just to see if it would work on a jagged edge, instead of a nice smooth surface, it has held for a year now. Now, having said that, I must say, I have not put that particular coffee cup, into the microwave, as I am not sure what that amount of heat would do to the glue. Make sure that you do not use more than it takes to do the job, as it spreads when it gets wet. I learned that lesson the hard way. I always have a bottle of it with me, or at least within arms reach, because you never know when it will come in handy.

item title: Magnum Media DUAL SCALE 0-32% Brix and 1.000-1.130SG Wort Refractometer RSG-100ATC Beer Home Brew
review: I waffled for a long time on which refractometer to buy for use when home brewing beer.  I knew because of the issues with alcohol being present that I would not use one of these for post-fermentation readings, but I wanted one for ease of checking pre-boil and post boil gravity.  This little unit works great, and was already calibrated accurately right out of the box.  All you have to do is grab a few drops of wort with the included dropper, place those on the sample panel, wait for them to cool (a few seconds) and view the results.  On my refractometer, the swiveling focus adjustment was a little crooked, but it turned out to just be the outer rubber housing and I was able to straighten it without much effort and with no negative ramifications.  This thing is accurate, convenient, and cheap.  I would buy it again in a heartbeat!

No more drafts, no more crickets invading my space! Even ants haven't figured out how to get in yet; but I did a very careful 1 piece installation, v-grooving the corners not trying to compress it into them or square butt them. Do it right and you'll love it as much as I did. Like the matteress ads, it springs back, doesn't stay flat. Open the door and in minutes the foam recovers to it's original thickness.

item title: Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 2 ounce Bottle, Brown, (Pack of 4)
review: Review updated 9Aug12  1) Elmers "Ultimate High Performance" and "Sticky Ass" are also Polyurethane (PU) glues and (as far as I can tell) they're as good as Gorilla but less expensive. I have also used PL brand and can't tell any notable difference between the four. Have not used Sumo but I understand it sets up faster and as a result apparently has a much more limited shelf life (this is generally not a good thing - see item #3)  2) Gorilla Glue (In my opinion) has thought out their bottle and cap design better than the competition.  While this seems like a minor thing, it really makes a BIG difference in not being messy or wasting glue (See #4)  3) PU glues work differently - they foam up and expand in the presence of moisture and then harden.  This means you will need to think about where the glue comes out and how to keep it from making a mess.  Masking tape is your friend.  4) PU glues have a limited shelf life and you probably don't need as much as you think. Due to the expansion (see #3) you use a LOT less than other types of glue. 4 oz should be MORE than enough for most people, 8 oz is a BIG bottle. I personally buy the 2 oz bottle unless I have a major project.  PU Glues suck moisture out of the air so unless you plan on using it up within a year or two, a LOT is going to go to waste. Don't ask me how I know this.  5) PU Glue is FANTASTIC for lots of things but woodworking glues are still better for woodworking (see #7). They are stronger and you can't clean PU glues up with water the way you can even with the waterproof Titebond products. Also if you use biscuits you will have to moisten them separately to get them to swell.  6) KEEP OUT OF REACH OF CHILDREN AND ANIMALS! Although the glue itself is not toxic and is food safe once cured, it can kill your pets - like antifreeze it apparently tastes good to animals and will swell and harden inside the digestive tract creating a blockage. There is NO antidote and surgery is typically the only solution. There have been MANY cases - just search Google "Dog Gorilla Glue." Wear gloves (rubber or vinyl) and use lots of wax paper and paper towels.  7) Wood glues (Like Titebond II) are still better for wood to wood bonding.  Fine Woodworking did a test (Issue #192) and found Polyurethane glues to be about half as strong in this application.  Search "HowStrongisYourGlue_FWW" for the article.  One exception is if you're gluing oily exotics where I still prefer Epoxy - you can dial in your set time, clean up is about the same given the PU glue outflow.  If you have questions or comments, or if you have found this review helpful, please let me know!
historical interactions: ['Gorilla 5000408  Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 4 ounce Bottle, Brown', 'Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 8 ounce Bottle, Brown', 'Uranium Ore', 'Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 2 ounce Bottle, Brown']
output:

Next, the user talked about how PU glues work—they expand when moisture is present and then harden. This means they need to be careful with where they apply the glue and use masking tape. They compared PU glues to wood glue, like Titebond II, pointing out that wood glue is stronger for woodworking tasks. They referenced a test where PU glues were about half as strong for wood bonding. However, they mentioned that for oily exotics, epoxy might be better, but PU can be used with the right set time.

Additionally, the user warned about the dangers of Gorilla glue for pets. It can kill pets by absorbing their food, so they advised using gloves, wax paper, and paper towels.

Looking at the historical interactions, the user has bought 2-ounce and 4-ounce bottles of Gorilla Gorilla Glue. They seem to prefer smaller sizes unless it's a major project, indicating they're cost-conscious or don't need large amounts.

item title: 6061 Aluminum Rectangular Bar, Unpolished (Mill) Finish, Extruded, T6511 Temper, ASTM B221, 1/8" Thickness, 1" Width, 36" Length
review: Aluminum 6061-T6 Rectangular Bar  The 6061-T6 rectangular bars, " thick, 1-1/2" wide, 4' long, arrived without damage.  It was packaged in a stiff cardboard tube for protection; tube ends had wooden plugs stapled in place so the contents couldn't come out.  They've thought this through.  Aluminum is easy to drill, cut with a hacksaw, sand, mill, polish, or tap for machine screws.  See Customer Images for a sample project.  Google on Aluminum alloys if you're curious about aluminum types (e.g., some are better for welding).  Wikipedia has an excellent description of 6061-T6.  Here's what OnLineMetals web site says about 6061 aluminum:  6061 Aluminum is, by most any measure, the most commonly used aluminum alloy. It is specified in most any application due to its strength, heat treatability, comparatively easy machining, and weldability. If that were not enough, it is also capable of being anodized, adding a layer of protection for finished parts.  The main alloy ingredients of 6061 aluminum are magnesium and silicon.  If you need to contact OnLineMetals, their number is 800-704-2157.

We have used it to repair wooden chairs, fix a wooden medicine chest, glue soles back on to sneekers, fill cracks in a wall, and at least half a dozen other fixes in the past month.  Here are my observations:  * You must read the directions! * Surface needs to be damp for the glue to work * Use clamps when possible * It expands a *LOT*, use with caution or you might accidently glue your project to the table as it expands overnight! This happend to me :-) * This is strong glue and hard to get off once it is on a surface  Highly recommended!

item title: J-B Weld 50176 KwikWeld Steel Reinforced Epoxy Syringe - Dries Dark Grey - 25 ml
review: This is a great epoxy in a reusable syringe. I have used both regular J-B and Kwik weld and they always work great as an epoxy. Obviouslyl you have to clean the surface of anything you are going to epoxy as it won't stick to oil/grease. I have used on metal, plastic and wood and results are always excellent. But the best feature is this new reusable syringe. It allows you to get an exact equal measurement of the resin and hardener. It also has the best locking cap I have seen yet. All other epoxy syringes use a simple push on cap but this J-B Kwik weld syringe uses a locking cap that you put in place and then twist to lock it. No more caps falling off or getting pushed off if you accidentally push on the syringe. Overall one of the best epoxies with the best dispenser yet. Highly recommended but always be sure to clean, scuff or sand the surface.

item title: Scotch Heavy Duty Shipping Packaging Tape, 3" Core, 1.88" x 54.6 Yards, 6-Rolls (3850-6)
review: I thought it was me until I read the other complaints about the Scotch Super Strength Tape not sticking to packages. While this may be a very strong (labeled 20x stronger) packaging tape, it's not much good if it won't stick to the package.  I had previously used an off-brand very inexpensive packaging tape and never had any problems with it not sticking. In fact the cheap tape was very sticky, so much so that if you pulled it off the package, it pulled the top layer of the cardboard with it. On the other hand, the expensive Scotch Super Strength tape pulls off any package with no problem. I am using 2-3 times as much tape (criss-crossing it) as I did with the cheap tape. So the Scotch ends up costing me 4-5 times as much. Overall a real reputation killer for Scotch brand products.

item title: FLIR TG54 Spot Infrared Thermometer
review: This FLIR TG130 Spot Thermal Camera is good quality and is very easy to use. I have several IR cameras, including two others from FLIR and one from SEEK, and this is by far the quickest and easiest use.  The unit takes 3xAAA batteries (included) and has very few controls, just an On/Off Button, a "Hold" Button, and a switch in the battery compartment for the C/F Setting. The screen is fairly low resolution but it is clear enough to easily recognize what the camera is showing. It has a "Target" in the center of the image and a continuous readout of the temperature being read.  Unlike all of my other IR cameras, this does not allow saving of the images so I have "Held" the image and taken a picture of the screen with my phone when I needed to remember a reading.  Overall, this is a very good choice for anyone wanting to find household insulation issues and other casual usage.  Highly Recommended!  CFH

item title:  Sparco Folding Platform Truck, 660 lbs, 24-3/4 x 36 x 29-1/2 Inches, Blue (SPR02040)
review: This is a very sturdy and handy platform hand truck.  The wheels are large which is both a benefit and a disadvantage, but the advantage of having large wheels which can be used outside in semi-soft areas such as lawn much outweighs the disadvantage of wheels taking up a lot of storage space when it is folded.  I have used it to move around trees planted in LARGE containers, 3-400 lb packages of ceramic tiles, 4-6 80 lb bags of sand and cement, even loaded it with 30 concrete blocks one time and it has held up extremely well.  ( I do NOT recommend trying to push the 6 bags of sand over soft lawn though -- live and learn.  Even the large wheels sink in then.)

item title: Tech Med 85954 Quick Release Tourniquet, Red
review: DO NOT BUY!!  I had hoped to use this "tourniquet" in my car & "grab & go" first aid kit.  It is unfit except for most basic home use.  It is truly a "Quick Release" though!  Unless it is exactly positioned correctly it releases on its own!!!  Plastic locking mechanism is flimsy and of very poorly engineered, cheap lightweight, plastic.  I would not trust it to hold unattended and unobserved for 30 seconds!!  It also locks, if you can call it that in a manner that creates "pinching" pressure point under the locking mechanism.  The elastic strap is also of very weak material.  As a former Navy corpsman and Marine Corps field corpsman, I do not believe this so called tourniquet would be effective for any but hand or food arterial bleeds.  It is NOT to be trusted stop or significantly decrease any arterial bleed of arm or leg.  It is best described as a quick release constriction band of poor quality and questionable engineering.  AVOID!

item title: Uxcell a14092200ux1053 LED Pilot Light Panel Indicator (Pack of 3)
review: Indicator LEDs  These lamps require a 7/8" diameter hole to mount, in material up to 3/16" thick.  The rubber gasket against the face plate keeps dust and moisture out.  To secure the lamp there's a tightening nut from the back.  Tighten by hand or carefully with a wrench.  Should the bulb die (which is unlikely), the lamp itself is easier to replace with a new one than a lamp with a soldered connection.  Ive mounted these outside and they are waterproof.  These are quite large -- just over an inch in diameter for the colored plastic and they extend rear-ward about 2" behind the mounting plate.  They are sufficiently bright when mounted inside.  However, outside, even on a cloudy day, you cant be sure they are on from even a foot away.  To make them a little brighter, unscrew the colored lens, remove the white diffuser and screw that lens back on being careful not to cross-thread.  They will now be visible at some distance, but only if looking directly at them; so for an outdoor (daylight) installation, consider something else.  You can't wire them until the nut is secured or they won't fit through a 7/8" hole.  The tiny screws used to clamp a wire down will hold up to a 14 gauge wire.  Solid or stranded will fit, but since stranded is flexible, it imposes much less stress (on the lamp connectors) during the install.  To ensure that each wire is properly held down, pull the black rear cap off with needle nose pliers, securely tighten the screw holding each wire and snap the back cover on.  These are designed to work with 110-120 volts, but are usable on 220v by connecting one hot and a neutral to the lamp.

item title: Genie 34107R.S Screw Drive Carriage
review: Genie 34107R.S Screw Drive Carriage  The life-span of this part depends on many factors, such as the lift-force needed to raise your garage door, how often you open the door, and whether you regularly grease the screw drive.  Some owner's carriage threads wear down within a few years, while it lasts 10 years or more for others.  Mine lasted 7 years raising a double door.  In any case, this part is a weak mechanical link of all Genie screw drive openers, because it's destined to fail.  As shown in Customer Images, the carriage threads are only 1/4" wide and 2 5/8" long, and made of aluminum (zinc?).  That's designed-in obsolescence since the entire force of lifting the garage door is on that tiny area - even more so when the carriage crosses a drive screw joint, a 1" gap with no screw threads at all.  Genie should have made the carriage threads much wider and longer, and reduced that 1" gap, to preclude carriage failures.  If you hear a loud metallic clunk when your garage door is raising, it could be the carriage.  It's pretty easy to tell if that's what it is - the noise occurs when the carriage transverses the screw section nearest the door and the one adjoining it; where there are no screw threads.  The "clunk" noise is from the carriage threads breaking apart. A few days after that first clunk, while our door was 3' off the ground and going up, the carriage threads failed completely, and the door fell to the floor with a loud bang.  A free-falling garage door is a serious hazard, especially to children and pets.  Our door is balanced, in that it will stay in place by itself (with the carriage freed) at the mid-height point.  However, if it's only two or three feet off the floor, it will fall quickly.  My advice is to immediately stop using the door opener if the carriage is failing.  I.e., open & close the door manually until you can replace the part.  Replacement only takes 10-15 minutes, once you have the tools assembled.  No instructions are included, but here are my recommended steps:  - unplug the opener  - remove the hitch pin from the pull-bar (attached to the garage door) and lower the pull-bar.  - pull the rope un-locker down, freeing the carriage  - remove the single bolt where the aluminum track connects to the bracket over the garage door.  If the track would fall to the ground without you holding it, temporarily support it.  - slide the old carriage toward the door and while holding the track to one side, remove the carriage.  - reverse the above steps to install the new carriage, with the carriage facing the correct direction.  An arrow pointing toward the garage door is molded into the carriage.  - move the puller-rope to the new carriage.  - apply grease to the drive-screw if you haven't done that recently.  You may be able to talk Genie into sending you this part for free, if you have the life-time opener warranty.  Although this is an OEM replacement part, I rated it at 3 stars because the carriage threads are too small, so eventual part failure is a given.

item title: 3M Vetbond Tissue Adhesive, 3ml Bottles w/MSDS
review: Be very careful in using this product, it is medical grade superglue and you can easily glue your fingers together if not careful. For those wounds, cuts and cracks where nothing else works, this might. It can glue skin together. I'm not recommending you use it on humans but I have to admit to using to close skin cracks (I work with wood and that dries my fingers out badly) and it works better than any other product I have ever tried. Band-Aid used to have a similar 2 part product that acted like superglue when you mixed the two parts together but they discontinued it and I searched and tried quite a few other products before finding this. It works great and no sting and no ill effects that I can determine.

input: item title: Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 8 ounce Bottle, Brown review: I have tried three different types of Gorilla glue and this one is the best, although still VERY average. I cannot recommend it as it is not truly "general purpose". While it works decently, if you don't mind the excess foaming on paper to wood, wood to wood or cardboard to plastic, it totally fails on plastic to metal or brick. It is WORTHLESS on brick to brick (yes they are bare, unpainted bricks), and don't even think about using it to stick anything to concrete blocks. Their Product Description is all hype and I found to be totally untrue. "Gorilla Glue is the finest all purpose premium polyurethane wood glue available today." * I have found several better products, including Elmer's Ultimate Glue - P9417 16Oz Ultimate Poly Glue and Elmer's E9416 All Purpose Glue-All Max, 8 Ounces just to name two. "Gorilla Glue is environmentally friendly, incredibly strong, 100 waterproof, will not freeze, requires no mixing, does not become brittle with age and will not expand or contract in the glue joint." * It is NOT incredibly strong!! I first tried to glue a plastic wheel barrow what has a 6 in split in it with this this product. After TWO days of drying (and scraping a lot of foaming residue) I dumped a load of dirt and it immediately split on first load. Okay, maybe not enough surface area to make a good bond. I took a strip of flexible plastic and roughed up both original surfaces and the new reinforcement strip and surface that would be in contact with it with 80 grit sandpaper, AND I also CLAMPED the reinforcement strip firmly, but not tightly, in 3 locations. Again, after 3 or 4 days (home owner, don't have to use wheel barrow every day luckily) of setting time I went to use wheelbarrow. Put shovel in wheelbarrow and let handle drop to side. Guess what? Yup, you guessed it, crack split again faster than cheerleaders doing splits at end of their routine! So much for strong. * It has become brittle on two or three projects for me, mostly ones exposed to intense sunlight or freezing temperatures. And then FAILED. As to water proof & requires no mixing, I guess these are correct, but so are almost all other resin and polyurethane adhesives; environmentally friendly -- what about it is enviro friendly? More hype to get tree huggers and green freaks to buy a product I suppose. * * Plus this stuff foams up worse than a dog that has just tried to eat a toad and is very messy to clean up and it surface even when capped tightly in bottle tends to become rock hard and requires coat hanger to break up to get to adhesive. I have relegated what I have left to NON critical small insignificant wood/paper bonding and will NOT be purchasing again. historical interactions: [' Sparco Folding Platform Truck, 660 lbs, 24-3/4 x 36 x 29-1/2 Inches, Blue (SPR02040)', ' Sparco Folding Platform Truck, 660 lbs, 24-3/4 x 36 x 29-1/2 Inches, Blue (SPR02040)', 'Tech Med 85954 Quick Release Tourniquet, Red', 'Gorilla Tape, Black Duct Tape, 1.88" x 35 yd, Black, (Pack of 1)']

item title: Gorilla Glue Adhesive, 2-Ounces #50001
review: "Gorilla Glue" has become one of the most used "tools" in our house. We have used it to repair wooden chairs, fix a wooden medicine chest, glue soles back on to sneekers, fill cracks in a wall, and at least half a dozen other fixes in the past month.  Here are my observations:  * You must read the directions! * Surface needs to be damp for the glue to work * Use clamps when possible * It expands a *LOT*, use with caution or you might accidently glue your project to the table as it expands overnight! This happend to me :-) * This is strong glue and hard to get off once it is on a surface  Highly recommended!

item title: T-Rex 241309 Shurtech Ferociously Strong Tape, 12 Yd L X 1.88 in W, 1-Roll, 12 Yards, Gunmetal Gray
review: I've tried the Gorilla duct tape and also the Iron Grip.  They held fairly well, but the most challenging application I have is in the garden - lots of dirt and water.  I was using some gaffers tape on some bucket handles and it wouldn't stay stuck more than a season. This stuff is working well so far, will update at the end of the summer.  The picture is this tape at the bottom of a 25 gallon tub - we use it in the garden as an overflow from a rain barrel.  Holding up, leak-proof so far.  I did clean the surface well with both detergent and rubbing alcohol.  As far as I can tell, the tape is as strong as the Gorilla and a little bit better than the Iron Grip, adhesive is at least as good as the Gorilla.

input:
item title: Eclipse Quick Release Woodworking Vise, Gray Cast Iron, 9" Size
review: Right out of the box, the release mechanism seemed a little too stiff, so I slacked it off.  This was not terribly difficult to do while I had the vise apart to clean off the shipping grease and attach it.  As a result of loosening the quick release lever spring, the mechanism can hang "mid thread" and only partially engage the screw at times.  Turning the screw then causes it to "snap" suddenly back into the threads.  A slight trade-off, but one I feel is worthwhile as the mechanism was too stiff for me to comfortably operate beforehand.  I applied white lithium grease to the rails and screw and go over the handle with scotch-brite and firearms CLP to keep the rust at bay, as I am handling it with sweaty hands.  The mechanism operates smoothly and solidly to its full extension without excessive play.  After using it for several months of planing and chiseling everything from mallet heads to 12ft long dimensional lumber, I can say it easily meets or exceeds my workholding needs every time.

item title: Loc-Line Coolant Hose Assembly Kit, Acetal Copolymer, 7 Piece, 1/4" Coolant Hose ID
review: I "borrowed" a scroll saw from my MIL (she's had it for 10 plus years and never even plugged it in!)  The dust blower works, but unfortunatly she lost the air hose and nozzle.  Well aquarium air tubing (silicon tubing NOT the vinyl) fit the nozzel, but was too flexible to stay in place, and really only did a mediocre job at blowing away the saw dust.  This little kit saved the day!  I was able to slip it over the silicon tubing and onto the saw nozzle.  It fits nice and tight and the loc line stays positioned exactly where I need it, even with the saws vibration.  Even after several hours of cutting it is still perfect!  I do recomment the pliers as these 1/4" fittings are pretty small and hard to grip.  The pliers make quick work of attaching and removing fittings.  I'm now looking for other projects that this stuff can be used on.

item title: Vintage Shop PW-COIA-QACH Hydrometer 12" Test Jar with Removable Base
review: I have been homebrewing for almost a year now and have many successful 5 gallon batches under my belt.  When I first started, I used the plastic bottle my hydrometer came in as a test jar, but that was less than ideal as the cheap thin plastic was not very strong and the base was not very stable when I stood it on the counter full of beer.  After upgrading to this model I have been much happier with the results.  The base is wide so I don't have to worry about the thing tipping over and the clear plastic is very sturdy.  An added bonus is that the base unscrews from the clear barrel so that both can be washed and sanitized.  My only complaint about this testing jar is that its width equates to more volume and that means more beer lost each time I do a test.  So in a roundabout way, it has forced me to take fewer gravity readings, which probably isn't a terrible thing!  Highly recommended.

item title: 3Doodler 2.0 + 2 plastic packs + US plug
review: Summary: Super fun, ideal for ages ~9 and up, though good for as young as ~6-7 with supervision...  I missed out on the Kickstarter for the 3Doodler 1.0, and in hindsight that was a good thing.  From what I can tell, the 3Doodler 2.0 is a much, much improved product.  That said, its still not perfect, and so takes some tuning / getting used to.  I managed to score my 2.0 on Kickstarter this time, and have been playing with it nonstop for over a week.  It does take some getting used to - the first ~2 strands I used didn't amount to anything, but I've just finished a cool mechanical sculpture.  >>>Starting up the pen First of all, you have to realize that the feed mechanism has a long lead-in.  This means that from when the pen grabs the strand to when you start to get extruded melt takes time  like a good minute or so.  Take a look at where the strand is feeding into the pen, and if you can see it moving in, continue waiting.  Only if it appears stalled should you start to rotate the strand (gently) clockwise.  >>>Shutting down the pen If Im planning to start back up with the same strand, I will back the strand up 10 blinks, then unplug.  ODepending on what I plan to do, I will either remove the strand  >>>Adjusting the pen temperature For now I am finding it easier to work in 2D, then assemble the pieces into 3D.  This means its easier to work with a higher temp  about half a rotation on the adjustment screw.  If I want to extrude a thread which stands, I blow on it gently as it comes out to cool it faster.  As I get better, I will likely turn the temp back down.  One plus of the higher temp is better welding and faster feed, though there might be a higher risk of jamming.  >>>Jamming My theory on the distance between the feed gears and the melt chamber is that if the strand gets soft in the feed gears, it jams.  Note that the instructions indicate that you may need to let the 3Doodler rest from time to time.  I suspect that this is because the pen gets too warm - my observation is that this tends to happen more when you let the pen sit.  If you keep drawing and feeding more strand in, it doesn't have time to get hot inside the feed gears .  If the pen stops feeding while you're using it, give it a good few seconds, then back the strand out (press fast and slow feed simultaneously) then clip off the melted portion and start feeding again.  >>>ABS vs PLA They are not kidding about ventilation, though its much more with the ABS.  I ran about 3-4 strands through in the kitchen, which has decent airflow, but I got a bit of a headache from the smell.  Will set up a small fan nearby next time.  PLA on the other hand in our kitchen was no problem.  ABS does better standing structures though as it cools faster due to the higher melt temp.  >>>Coil stock I bought a ~1 lb spool of 3 mm PLA - it works perfectly except that you do have to straighten it out a little before you use it.  As the strand does rotate as it feeds, you need to also cut it to a managable length.  I've been cutting mine to perhaps 15" then manually unbending it a little.  This also softens up the PLA so its not as rigid.  I cut off a bunch at a time and re-vacuum seal the spool so it doesn't absorb moisture.  >>>Tips: 1) Use a fine tip sharpie to mark the strand when you're feeding - that way you can tell if it's moving or not 2) Get yourself a set of small diagonal cutters - much easier to snip the strand 3) Toss the larger silicone heat cover - it's useless and just gets in the way 4) Double press the slow feed to start up a new strand and go read a book.  Seriously though, it takes a lot longer than you think it should. 5) Get a clear flexible piece of plastic - I use a 5 mil empty laminating pouch.  I can then draw a pattern with pencil on paper, then use the 3Doodler to draw on the plastic - it sticks enough that you can work, then it pops off cleanly when finished. 6) Get a small fan to keep the area ventilated, and also to cool your projects as you are working on them 7) If you 3Doodler sketch is warped or bent, draw on it with some new material - this typically heats the part up enough that you can bend it a little, then hold it until it cools 8) Don't be afraid to incorporate other materials in your sketches - PLA in particular sticks very well to paper, toothpicks, wood blocks, etc.  If you have questions, comments, or found this review helpful, please let me know!

item title: Calculated Industries 7434 AccuMASTER 2-in 1 Magnetic Digital Level and Angle Finder / Inclinometer / Bevel Gauge, Latest MEMs Technology, Certified IP54 Dust and Water Resistant
review: This is a beautiful little tool. I was seriously surprised at how accurate this small tool is, especially for the price point of under thirty bucks. The first thing it has an aluminum body so its going to be tough. The second thing that strikes you is that the display numbers are very large and it is backlit in bright green. For those who wear reading glasses and remove them to put on safety glasses or goggles, you can easily see the numbers without the reading glasses they are that large and well lit.  This is so simple to use you will be up and running in a couple of minutes filling with it / toggling through the modes. I tested this around the house on things that I thought were level such as pictures on the wall and wow were they off. Being this accurate will be overkill for the weekend warrior, but that pretty much describes my never ending list of projects, and I am glad I have this little tool. It is so compact. It is the size of a small 12 foot measuring tape. I found myself using the inclination setting on pictures and paintings and it works well and fast. I had a question and the company answered in a few hours.  The gauge itself is magnetic and will attach to metal surface. The display is reversible so you can read it upside down.  Comes with nylon carry punch and loaded with aaa batteries ready to go. Has a plastic pull tab that you yank out to activate the fresh batteries. Two year warranty.

item title: Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 8 ounce Bottle, Brown
review: "Gorilla Glue" has become one of the most used "tools" in our house. We have used it to repair wooden chairs, fix a wooden medicine chest, glue soles back on to sneekers, fill cracks in a wall, and at least half a dozen other fixes in the past month.  Here are my observations:  * You must read the directions! * Surface needs to be damp for the glue to work * Use clamps when possible * It expands a *LOT*, use with caution or you might accidently glue your project to the table as it expands overnight! This happend to me :-) * This is strong glue and hard to get off once it is on a surface  Highly recommended!

They also used clamps, which makes sense because the glue expands a lot, especially overnight. They had an accident where the glue caused the project to stick to the table, so they learned to be careful and maybe keep clamps handy or something.

I think the user values convenience and reliability. They probably wanted a product that's easy to use, works well on various surfaces, and doesn't leave sticky residue. The fact that it expands a lot might have been a consideration for bigger projects, but they knew to be cautious.

input:
item title: Rothco Duct Tape
review: This is OK, medium-duty, plasticky duct tape.  It has been fairly sticky & strong in the applications I've tried it on.  But it is NOT fibrous and it's pretty thin, so it's really more about layering with this stuff, and I seriously doubt that this is the actual stuff used by the US military - at least I hope our troops are given better stuff.  Having said that, I've mended a tarp with it, re-affixed a trampoline safety net to the poles, used it to keep the ends of 3/4" rope from unravelling, and some other things I can't recall.  It seems to do the job ok, but I'm not sure about longevity.  By comparison I got some 3M heavy duty duct tape that truly feels and acts "heavy duty".  If this "military" duct tape was 1/2 the cost it might be worth it.

item title: da Vinci miniMaker 3D Printer ~ 6"x6"x6" Built Volume (Includes: $14 300g PLA Filament, 49 3D Design eBook, 10 Maintenance Tools, XYZmaker CAD 3D Software, PLA/Tough PLA/PETG/ Antibacterial PLA)
review: This XYZprinting da Vinci miniMaker 3D Printer is a good home or classroom entry level 3D printer. This is my 3rd XYZprinting 3D printer and by far the easiest to get up and running. Here are my observations:  Pros - + Quality; this is a sturdy unit + Print Quality; the models I printed are on par with the other XYZprinting printers + Ease of Use; this is so much easier to use than the earlier models, I had it up and running within a half hour of unboxing  Cons - - Proprietary Filament; you save on the price of the printer but will pay more for the company's filament  Misc - * Software; not as intuitive as most would like but it is possible to learn how to get the advanced features working with a little playing  Overall, this is a good entry level 3D printer for light use and learning about 3D printing!  Recommended!  CFH

item title: Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 2 ounce Bottle, Brown, (Pack of 4)
review: "Gorilla Glue" has become one of the most used "tools" in our house. We have used it to repair wooden chairs, fix a wooden medicine chest, glue soles back on to sneekers, fill cracks in a wall, and at least half a dozen other fixes in the past month.  Here are my observations:  * You must read the directions! * Surface needs to be damp for the glue to work * Use clamps when possible * It expands a *LOT*, use with caution or you might accidently glue your project to the table as it expands overnight! This happend to me :-) * This is strong glue and hard to get off once it is on a surface  Highly recommended!

Putting it all together, the user is a hands-on person who appreciates a product that's reliable, easy to use, and effective. They value caution and don't want to waste time or materials on cleanup, so Gorilla Glue fits all those needs perfectly.

review: I was really disappointed with these calipers after reading all the positive reviews and I also have other iGaging tools. I let the calipers sit for a day to let the temperature stabilize to match my other measuring instruments. I used a precision 2" block as a check and it measured from .002+ to .002- depending on where on the jaws I made the measurement and I made sure it was exactly perpendicular to the jaws. I then used my digital micrometer and another digital caliper for comparison and both measured precisely 2.000 inches. The other digital caliper would measure the same from top to bottom of the jaws. The calibration check sheet that came with the calipers showed that this set of calipers was supposed to be right on but maybe something happened in shipping.

item title: 3Doodler 2.0 3D Printing Pen + 2 Packs of ABS Plastic Strands
review: Summary: Super fun, ideal for ages ~9 and up, though good for as young as ~6-7.  I missed out on the Kickstarter for the 3Doodler 1.0, and in hindsight that was a good thing.  From what I can tell, the 3Doodler 2.0 is a much, much improved product.  That said, its still not perfect, and so takes some tuning / getting used to.  I managed to score my 2.0 on Kickstarter this time, and have been playing with it nonstop for over a week.  It does take some getting used to - the first ~2 strands I used didn't amount to anything, but I've just finished a cool mechanical sculpture.  >>>Starting up the pen First of all, you have to realize that the feed mechanism has a long lead-in.  This means that from when the pen grabs the strand to when you start to get extruded melt takes time  like a good minute or so.  Take a look at where the strand is feeding into the pen, and if you can see it moving in, continue waiting.  Only if it appears stalled should you start to rotate the strand (gently) clockwise.  >>>Shutting down the pen If Im planning to start back up with the same strand, I will back the strand up 10 blinks, then unplug.  ODepending on what I plan to do, I will either remove the strand  >>>Adjusting the pen temperature For now I am finding it easier to work in 2D, then assemble the pieces into 3D.  This means its easier to work with a higher temp  about half a rotation on the adjustment screw.  If I want to extrude a thread which stands, I blow on it gently as it comes out to cool it faster.  As I get better, I will likely turn the temp back down.  One plus of the higher temp is better welding and faster feed, though there might be a higher risk of jamming.  >>>Jamming My theory on the distance between the feed gears and the melt chamber is that if the strand gets soft in the feed gears, it jams.  Note that the instructions indicate that you may need to let the 3Doodler rest from time to time.  I suspect that this is because the pen gets too warm - my observation is that this tends to happen more when you let the pen sit.  If you keep drawing and feeding more strand in, it doesn't have time to get hot inside the feed gears .  If the pen stops feeding while you're using it, give it a good few seconds, then back the strand out (press fast and slow feed simultaneously) then clip off the melted portion and start feeding again.  >>>ABS vs PLA They are not kidding about ventilation, though its much more with the ABS.  I ran about 3-4 strands through in the kitchen, which has decent airflow, but I got a bit of a headache from the smell.  Will set up a small fan nearby next time.  PLA on the other hand in our kitchen was no problem.  ABS does better standing structures though as it cools faster due to the higher melt temp.  >>>Coil stock I bought a ~1 lb spool of 3 mm PLA - it works perfectly except that you do have to straighten it out a little before you use it.  As the strand does rotate as it feeds, you need to also cut it to a managable length.  I've been cutting mine to perhaps 15" then manually unbending it a little.  This also softens up the PLA so its not as rigid.  I cut off a bunch at a time and re-vacuum seal the spool so it doesn't absorb moisture.  >>>Tips: 1) Use a fine tip sharpie to mark the strand when you're feeding - that way you can tell if it's moving or not 2) Get yourself a set of small diagonal cutters - much easier to snip the strand 3) Toss the larger silicone heat cover - it's useless and just gets in the way 4) Double press the slow feed to start up a new strand and go read a book.  Seriously though, it takes a lot longer than you think it should. 5) Get a clear flexible piece of plastic - I use a 5 mil empty laminating pouch.  I can then draw a pattern with pencil on paper, then use the 3Doodler to draw on the plastic - it sticks enough that you can work, then it pops off cleanly when finished. 6) Get a small fan to keep the area ventilated, and also to cool your projects as you are working on them 7) If you 3Doodler sketch is warped or bent, draw on it with some new material - this typically heats the part up enough that you can bend it a little, then hold it until it cools 8) Don't be afraid to incorporate other materials in your sketches - PLA in particular sticks very well to paper, toothpicks, wood blocks, etc.  If you have questions, comments, or found this review helpful, please let me know!

item title: Dyson Cinetic Animal Canister Vacuum
review: We have been using this new vacuum cleaner regularly for about three weeks now since we got it. It is a great vacuum for cars, stairs and dorms because of its portability and convenience of use.  Pros: - Suction. It literally sucks. The company is proud of Dysons powerful suction and its ability to stay strong even if the bag/canister is almost full. I agree with the claim. This is one of the strongest suckers I have seen and I have seen a lot. This house have seen a lot of vac from Orecks, Rainbow, Panasonic, Hoover, Electrolux, etc. - Weight. This is light enough to use by one person to clean the stairs. It is also perfect for cleaning the inside of your car. - No need to buy vacuum bags. Just click the red button and it will open the lid on the bottom. You would prefer to dump it outside as some of the dust may float in the air. - Built with convenience in all aspects of the design. All the accessories are just a snap to remove and replace. - Retractable cord - This can go even under very low furniture. - Easy to clean as most of the parts are easily removable.  Cons: - My main gripe which is why I am not rating this a 5-star product is the size of the canister. It fills up so quickly that I had to empty it several times when we do general house cleaning. - Not for all kind of floors. Will be difficult to use on shaggy carpets. The rollers stop spinning. - Has difficulty picking up larger objects (larger than corn kernels) on hard floors.
