item title: Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 8 ounce Bottle, Brown
review: Gorilla Glue eight ounce size. Most of us have been in a home repair situation that just keeps getting worse the more you get into it. When that happens worse means more cash to fix the problem. There are those who say just "do it right" or don't do it at all. You know who you are. I can agree with them, when there is money to use, but when there are no funds there is..... Gorilla Glue. Well here is my story.  I had a small problem that quickly spiraled into a carpenters truck payments. I had a loose toilet. Not a big deal right. Tried to usual tighter down the loose bolts. No help they just kept turning, which means the terrible and dreaded WOOOOOD ROTTTTTT. Yes Houston we have a problem. The tiolet flange that holds it in place was rotten from some sneaky water leak somewhere not visible. This insidious leak had taken its toll and caused great damage under the bathroom tile.  In comes repair guy 1 then second opinion guy. Remedy; You gotta take that toilet out, bust out all that floor tile, cut out the sub floor, put in new sub floor, put in new tile, new toilet flange, and re set toilet then grout everything. Estimate to "Do It Right" nearly two grand. Since you have a carpenter, then a tile guy, then a plumber guy. My heart sank as I knew how much cash I had at the time.  My thoughts. The floor seemed good everywhere but around the flange. The toilet while it would turn and lift on one side was still holding fair on one side. If only I could just shoer this thing up where it would be stable. I wish I could just shoot something in there that would fix everything and not go in debt.  How about Gorilla Glue. No that would just make a bigger mess. No here me out this might work. No it won't Gorilla Glue expands and will screw up everything. All this was the conversation i was having with myself in my head.  Ok lets do this but how to get it under the toilet. I took the bottle of glue and went to the hose department at home depot and found some clear plastic hose that would fit on the end.  The process. I lifted up one side of the toilet to inspect wood damage and condition. The rot was in the past and little moisture was present so the leak may have been partly condensation gone wild. Good news. Gorilla Glue activates with moisture. Didn't know that, so the conditions here are perfect. What the glue was now to do is to bond with the bad wood becoming super strong, water resistant, and hard as stone. it will make a bridge so to speak with the bad wood and the good wood, and Gorilla will bond with porcelain like grout does but stronger bond.  The attack. Hose on bottle, one side of toilet is lifted, hose inserted, squeezing and not much is happening as this glue is thick. Plan B, set glue bottle on floor use foot pressure. Eureka we have glue flow. Pumped about two ounces all around the toilet. Luckily the high pressure from my foot did not make the hose come off and get all over my shoes and the outside of the toilet.  Ok ok you knew it was going to happen. Yes the hose did come off and glue spewed all over my shoes and toilet. Cleaned it off and we are done almost. Remember the glue does expand while it dries filling up gaps as it forms it bonds. I was ready with a box cutter coming back in every ten minutes to inspect and trim.  All in all it worked. Solid as a rock. No leaks. Used some white silicone caulk around the base. The choice was either eight bucks for the glue, or nearly two grand that could better be used for other things like beer, new flat screen tv, taking the wife out to dinner sixty times, or other electronic man toys.  This glue saved me. In life you come across small things that work their way your heart for how well they help you or serve a purpose. Your uses and millage of course may vary. Good luck always.

Well after 20 years the clips are just plain worn out and no longer hold the sheets in place.  Well 1/4 sheet adhesive backed paper is WAY too expensive, and I have not found any full sheet sticky back.  I was just about to toss the sander in the garbage when I stumbled across these rolls.  I decided to give them a shot and I'm so glad I did.  The adhesive sticks well to even my 20 year old rubber pad.  The sandpaper is very durable and long lasting.  I'm using this mainly for wood, but won't hesitate to go after metal or fiberglass (should the need arise).  At only 20 cents a pop this is one of the most economical adhesive backed options around.  I'm gonna have to order a couple other grits cause this stuff is great.

item title: Gardner Bender 07315001126 LTB-400 Liquid Electrical Tape, Easy-on, Waterproof, Indoor/Outdoor Use, 4 Oz. Jar, Black, Bottle
review: I bought this because I needed a watertight connection for an LED exterior sensor light that I was installing.  This thing is pure black.  It is thick and has a rather large brush.  If you apply a very thin coat, it can dry in a few minutes; otherwise you would need to wait a few hours before it is completely dry.  It is also a good idea to put an layer of electrical tape on top of it because that connection can be uneven.  I think this would be perfect if the brush is smaller.  It is hard to control the amount of liquid tape during application because of the size of the brush.  I also think a white liquid tape would be better so it is better to see if there are any parts that I missed coating.

item title: Qualcraft 2601 Wall Jack, Red
review: It takes a little practice to get used to these, and I kind of feel like it's a case of "controlled chaos" working with them. There's a lot of things that can go wrong, so they are potentially very dangerous. I didn't realize the first time I used them when you get to the very top of the lift, the weight of the jacks themselves will tend to push the wall over. I was trying to stop the wall from moving, and both of the jacks in  unison were fighting against me. I was very lucky that one edge of the top plate caught against an adjacent wall long enough for me to pull the jack out of place. I would have lost the wall otherwise.  After that first little adventure I started to tie rope to the wall, but this is also a case of controlled chaos. If your ropes are too long, they can stretch, and the bottom of the wall can kick in and go over too. I find it best to get the walls within about 3 inches of plumb, brace the wall and get rid of the jacks. Then, and only then, push the wall into plumb.  These are very handy, but I would advise anyone using them to start with small walls (10') or so before approaching anything much heavier.  I can also say it takes about 45 min. to set everything up vs. about 15 min. with a helper. Of course if you have no helper, these are gold. Use nice straight 2x4's and be certain everything is well secured. Double up your 2x4's at the base or use the wind kit.

item title: WD-40 No Mess Pen (Pack of 2)
review: First of all, who would have thought that a product name WD-40 will become a household name? It is a terrible name. It is almost impossible to remember such a name unless they did something right. WD-40 is a great product! Just do a search for the list of uses for WD-40 and you'll be amazed. Only a list of what Chuck Norris can do can top that.  And this is now my favorite WD-40. I probably have bought 5 or more cans in different sizes in the past; all of them got lost before I finished them. For occasional users, this is the perfect size. It has a felt tip that releases a drop every time you push the pen down. No mess! In the past, I used the spray cans and it goes all over the place. This is a very convenient way of dispensing the content. It even has a stripe of transparent window so you can see how much is left - clever idea.  For larger areas of application, you should stick with the spray cans.

We ship Federally regulated items that are usually obviously are what they are and are also high value value to potential thieves that could target them in transit (happens quite often). This tape is useful as both a deterrent since it will be obvious if tampered with and as an indicator of potential problems for the receiver.  The tape is not meant to be used as shipping tape, but rather in conjunction with standard packing tape. This is placed over the seams so it would have to be cut or removed to get at items in the package.  The tape is good quality and fairly easy to tell if it has been tampered with in transit.  Highly Recommended!  CFH

item title: South Main Hardware 810180, 12'/1"", Silver Lashing Strap (2 Pack)
review: There are a lot better straps out there for better prices.  You just have to look.  These straps drive me crazy because they are on ly on as tight as you can strap them.  I wouldnt trust them for something heavy because of this.  No matter how hard you tug and pull you will never be happy with how tied down they are.  You need a ratchet tie down for this.  That being said, these or ok.  They aren't great and they won't convince me to start using them considering you can get a set of 4 heavy duty tiedowns from many hardware stores for a similar price.  You can use these for light work.  I would tie down light weight materials going to the dump, groceries or other things that don't necessarily need a tough fit.  I would not use these on quads in the back of your truck or motorcycles.  Anything that could shift and do damage to your vehicle isn't something you would want to use these on.  That being said these have applications.  They are quick to apply and quick to take off.  You don't have to worry about the ratchet getting tangles.  All in all is this worth the expense?  For me no, for you, who knows.  All I know is I can go to a local store and get 4 ratchet ties for the same price.

item title: Duda Energy Syringepk010 Industrial Syringes with 15G x 1-1/2" Blunt Tip Fill Needle and Plastic Cover, 10 mL (Pack of 10)
review: These syringes work great. A rigid protective shield is included that snaps on and off the needle.  The protective shield is necessary because these needles are sharp, and will easily pierce skin.  They are ground at about about a 50 degree angle, which is blunt compared to a standard hypodermic grind, but they are still very sharp.  A more accurate description would have been to call them short grind needles.  I blunted all ten of mine on a belt grinder by grinding the tips to 90 degrees.  I then replaced the grinding belt with a leather stropping belt, and beveled the outside edge removing the burr created by the grinding process. Now the needles are blunt, and may be handled safely.  This can be done with a fine toothed file, a whet stone, concrete floor, sand paper, or any number of abrasive methods.  You could just leave them in the state received and be careful. I ended up with a stainless steel needle length of one and 15 thirty seconds of an inch in length.  Just call it an inch and a half.  The overall length with plunger fully extended is nine inches.  With plunger fully depressed, six and three sixteenths inches.  Syringe diameter is five eighths of an inch.  The syringe plunger may be easily removed and replaced to facilitate cleaning. The syringes do not leak.  If you are dispensing a heavier fluid like 10 weight oil (transmission fluid) the needle can be unscrewed from the syringe for a faster flow rate, and reinstalled for thinner fluids, or not.  If it is important they do come individually packaged in sterile wrappers. They are economically priced, and the free shipping was via priority mail.  In my case they were delivered by the USPS on the third day following my order. If you are looking for a way to dispense fluids precisely, draw fluids from a container, or both; I think you will be satisfied with the product, price, and seller.  Just be aware that if blunt is important you will have to do the blunting yourself.  The "blunt tip" description results in a four star rating of an otherwise five star product. Even blunted, an 18 gauge needle is not something that should be left laying around where children may have access.
historical interactions: []
output:

So, the user is concerned about safety, especially since they have children around. 

They compared the needle grind to a 50-degree angle, which is blunt, but still pretty sharp. They took extra steps to make them safer by blunting them themselves using various methods like a belt grinder, leather stropping belt, and even a whetstone. This shows they prioritize safety over convenience, which might be why they went through the trouble to modify the needles.

The syringes are priced affordably and come individually wrapped, which is a plus for them. They also mention the packaging is sterile, which is important for hygiene. The packaging being separate suggests they value individual use and don't want cross-contamination. 

They highlighted the durability and non-leaking nature of the syringes, which makes them reliable for their needs. The fact that they can adjust the needle for different fluids (like oil vs. water) adds flexibility, which they seem to appreciate.

item title: 3Doodler 2.0 3D Printing Pen + 2 Packs of ABS Plastic Strands
review: Summary: Super fun, ideal for ages ~9 and up, though good for as young as ~6-7 with supervision...  I missed out on the Kickstarter for the 3Doodler 1.0, and in hindsight that was a good thing. From what I can tell, the 3Doodler 2.0 is a much, much improved product. That said, its still not perfect, and so takes some tuning / getting used to. I managed to score my 2.0 on Kickstarter this time, and have been playing with it nonstop for over a week. It does take some getting used to - the first ~2 strands I used didn't amount to anything, but I've just finished a cool mechanical sculpture.  >>>Starting up the pen First of all, you have to realize that the feed mechanism has a long lead-in. This means that from when the pen grabs the strand to when you start to get extruded melt takes time  like a good minute or so. Take a look at where the strand is feeding into the pen, and if you can see it moving in, continue waiting. Only if it appears stalled should you start to rotate the strand (gently) clockwise.  >>>Shutting down the pen If Im planning to start back up with the same strand, I will back the strand up 10 blinks, then unplug. ODepending on what I plan to do, I will either remove the strand  >>>Adjusting the pen temperature For now I am finding it easier to work in 2D, then assemble the pieces into 3D. This means its easier to work with a higher temp  about half a rotation on the adjustment screw. If I want to extrude a thread which stands, I blow on it gently as it comes out to cool it faster. As I get better, I will likely turn the temp back down. One plus of the higher temp is better welding and faster feed, though there might be a higher risk of jamming.  >>>Jamming My theory on the distance between the feed gears and the melt chamber is that if the strand gets soft in the feed gears, it jams. Note that the instructions indicate that you may need to let the 3Doodler rest from time to time. I suspect that this is because the pen gets too warm - my observation is that this tends to happen more when you let the pen sit. If you keep drawing and feeding more strand in, it doesn't have time to get hot inside the feed gears . If the pen stops feeding while you're using it, give it a good few seconds, then back the strand out (press fast and slow feed simultaneously) then clip off the melted portion and start feeding again.  >>>ABS vs PLA They are not kidding about ventilation, though its much more with the ABS. I ran about 3-4 strands through in the kitchen, which has decent airflow, but I got a bit of a headache from the smell. Will set up a small fan nearby next time. PLA on the other hand in our kitchen was no problem. ABS does better standing structures though as it cools faster due to the higher melt temp.  >>>Coil stock I bought a ~1 lb spool of 3 mm PLA - it works perfectly except that you do have to straighten it out a little before you use it. As the strand does rotate as it feeds, you need to also cut it to a managable length. I've been cutting mine to perhaps 15" then manually unbending it a little. This also softens up the PLA so its not as rigid. I cut off a bunch at a time and re-vacuum seal the spool so it doesn't absorb moisture.  >>>Tips: 1) Use a fine tip sharpie to mark the strand when you're feeding - that way you can tell if it's moving or not 2) Get yourself a set of small diagonal cutters - much easier to snip the strand 3) Toss the larger silicone heat cover - it's useless and just gets in the way 4) Double press the slow feed to start up a new strand and go read a book. Seriously though, it takes a lot longer than you think it should. 5) Get a clear flexible piece of plastic - I use a 5 mil empty laminating pouch. I can then draw a pattern with pencil on paper, then use the 3Doodler to draw on the plastic - it sticks enough that you can work, then it pops off cleanly when finished. 6) Get a small fan to keep the area ventilated, and also to cool your projects as you are working on them 7) If you 3Doodler sketch is warped or bent, draw on it with some new material - this typically heats the part up enough that you can bend it a little, then hold it until it cools 8) Don't be afraid to incorporate other materials in your sketches - PLA in particular sticks very well to paper, toothpicks, wood blocks, etc.  If you have questions, comments, or found this review helpful, please let me know!

item title: XYZprinting ABS Plastic Filament Cartridge, 1.75 mm Diameter, 600g, Black
review: This XYZprinting ABS Plastic Filament Cartridge works very well in my XYZprinting 1.0 AiO, producing good quality prints. I ordered the "Olivine", which is just about the perfect color for printing little army men.  The cartridge fit perfectly and was recognized by the printer without any issues. The ABS prints can be sanded to smooth out the layering lines but it really responds well to being rubbed with a cloth dampened with acetone. Damaged prints can also be repaired using a slurry made of acetone and dissolved ABS scraps.  Highly Recommended!  CFH

item title: Zoeller 30-0181 PVC Plastic Check Valve, 1-1/2 Inch
review: Zoeller 30-0181 Check Valve & Union  Each end of this valve has a stepped outside diameter; 1.25" on the end, and 1.50" next to the valve body; refer to the Customer Images.  It comes with two rubber adapters and four stainless steel clamps.  The adapters convert 1.25" to 1.5" or vice-versa.  The 1.5" adapter end will slip over a 1.5" PVC pipe, and 1.25" will slip over a 1.25" PVC pipe.  In other words, using the supplied rubber adapters, either end can be configured to 1.25" or 1.5".  It's easy to connect this device using a clamp screw.  To remove the device, or slip one end off a pipe, loosen one of the clamp screws and slide the pipe out; hence "union" in the name.  This feature allows removal of the sump pump for service or replacement, without cutting any pipe.  This is a full flow check valve, unlike some models at my local Lowes or Home Depot, which partially restrict flow.  When a sump pump comes on, the valve flap swings completely out of the way, to allow maximum flow.  When the pump stops, the flap closes to stop water from going toward the pump. The rubber seal part of the flap will eventually leak a bit, I suppose, but there is so little pressure on it when it's closed, that it should last a long time.  Our sump pumps were installed with a check valve within the sump basin, since the discharge level was less than a foot above the sump basin.  When the pump shuts off, if you don't have a check valve, all water still in your exit pipe that's higher than the pump will flow back into the basin.  Otherwise, the only water that will flow backward into the basin is the small volume of water between the pump and the check valve.  In addition, a check valve prevents mice, insects, etc. that crawled in through your exit pipe, from making it all the way to your sump pump.  When the water comes on, critters should be washed away.  We have this check valve on each of our sump pumps.  Excellent product.
historical interactions: []
output:
chain of thought: Alright, I need to figure out why someone would buy the Zoeller 30-0181 PVC Plastic Check Valve. Let me look at the review and historical items. The review mentions that this valve is used in sump pumps, which are installed in basins where the discharge level is just a foot above. Without a check valve, water could flow back into the basin when the pump shuts off, which is a problem. The valve prevents water from flowing back and also stops mice and insects from getting into the system. It's a full flow check valve, unlike others they saw, which only partially restrict flow. The rubber seal might leak a bit, but it lasts a long time because there's little pressure when closed. The valve is easy to connect and remove, making maintenance easier. So, the main reasons are preventing water backflow, protecting the pump from damage, and being easy to maintain. Therefore, the primary reason for purchase is to prevent water backflow in sump systems.
answer: The primary reason for purchasing the Zoeller 30-0181 Check Valve is to prevent water backflow in sump systems, ensuring water does not flow back into the basin when the pump shuts off, thus protecting the pump and preventing damage.

item title: Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 8 ounce Bottle, Brown
review: Once you get familiar with with how this works, then it's easier to strategize how and when to use it.  It's very messy to work with and takes a long while to set up.  I've used GG (and other brands of the same type of glue - which, incidentally, seem to be identical to the point that I don't really have a preference) for countless things over the years:  I repaired the broken frame of a Nordictrack skier that developed a crack (I glued the crack and clampled it, as well as glueing and screwing a piece of wood to the side, along the crack and a few inches beyond on either side), put a kickboard on the screen door of our front door which is starting to deteriorate at the lower corner, built a small playhouse ladder, and about a million other things I can't recall.  It works well and bonds seem to be very strong.  I generally use glue as a supplement, not as the only source of bonding (if possible).  I've repaired some non-wood items as well.  Some have worked fine, some not.  As another review mentions, you can peel the dried glue off of the nozzle when you're opening it for another use - so it's probably not the best choice for plastics.  I've done some ceramics and it's been fine - the foaming as it dries can of course make the end results look less-than-perfect.  Overall GG is very useful, and there are plenty of things for which it works very well and where, say, super glue doesn't do the trick.  I don't know if it's better than wood glue for wood projects.  From what I hear it's not, but I don't always have wood glue around, so I'll use this.  The most important advice I can give is: don't buy too big of a bottle unless you really use it a lot.  When you're done using it, squeeze as much air out of the bottle as you can.  I've never been able to actually finish a bottle of this kind of glue, because as I get to the last third or so, it usally hardens or there's so much dried glue at the top of the bottle that I have to cut apart the bottle to get to the remaining glue.  Squeezing out as much air as possible before closing the cap will mitigate this to a large degree, but at some point you just can't get enough air out and so you start to see the crusty, hardened end of the life of your precious bottle of glue somewhere on the horizon.  It's the circle of life.  For glue, anyway.
historical interactions: ['Rothco Duct Tape', 'Caster Classics 2-inch Low Profile HD Rubber Wheel Plate Casters - 4-Pack']

item title:  KR Tools 72018 Pro Series 6-Inch Digital Caliper
review: This digital caliper is very easy to use.  It has large digits for easy reading.  It comes with 2 batteries, one of them is for spare.  As with regular calipers, you can measure outside and inside dimensions as well as the depth.  It comes with its own protective case.  Very useful if you are involved with precise measurement of pipes, rods, etc.  Indispensable to us when I used to helped my brother in law working on projects using lathe machines.  I love the simplicity of using only 3 buttons.  These button are also color coded so you can quickly memorize them.  1.  A button to switch between english to metric 2.  An on and off  button 3.  A quick zero button for calibration  It also operates as an analog caliper if you really want to use it  that way.  What it is really good for is you can have the measurement converted to either inch or mm in an instant.  You do not have to re-read the other side of the slide, just a mere push of a button.  But the LCD is nice as you can verify your readings, and it is very accurate too.  The only thing I notice is that the sliding motion is not very smooth.

item title: Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 2 ounce Bottle, Brown
review: Review updated 9Aug12  1) Elmers "Ultimate High Performance" and "Sticky Ass" are also Polyurethane (PU) glues and (as far as I can tell) they're as good as Gorilla but less expensive. I have also used PL brand and can't tell any notable difference between the four. Have not used Sumo but I understand it sets up faster and as a result apparently has a much more limited shelf life (this is generally not a good thing - see item #3)  2) Gorilla Glue (In my opinion) has thought out their bottle and cap design better than the competition.  While this seems like a minor thing, it really makes a BIG difference in not being messy or wasting glue (See #4)  3) PU glues work differently - they foam up and expand in the presence of moisture and then harden.  This means you will need to think about where the glue comes out and how to keep it from making a mess.  Masking tape is your friend.  4) PU glues have a limited shelf life and you probably don't need as much as you think. Due to the expansion (see #3) you use a LOT less than other types of glue. 4 oz should be MORE than enough for most people, 8 oz is a BIG bottle. I personally buy the 2 oz bottle unless I have a major project.  PU Glues suck moisture out of the air so unless you plan on using it up within a year or two, a LOT is going to go to waste. Don't ask me how I know this.  5) PU Glue is FANTASTIC for lots of things but woodworking glues are still better for woodworking (see #7). They are stronger and you can't clean PU glues up with water the way you can even with the waterproof Titebond products. Also if you use biscuits you will have to moisten them separately to get them to swell.  6) KEEP OUT OF REACH OF CHILDREN AND ANIMALS! Although the glue itself is not toxic and is food safe once cured, it can kill your pets - like antifreeze it apparently tastes good to animals and will swell and harden inside the digestive tract creating a blockage. There is NO antidote and surgery is typically the only solution. There have been MANY cases - just search Google "Dog Gorilla Glue." Wear gloves (rubber or vinyl) and use lots of wax paper and paper towels.  7) Wood glues (Like Titebond II) are still better for wood to wood bonding.  Fine Woodworking did a test (Issue #192) and found Polyurethane glues to be about half as strong in this application.  Search "HowStrongisYourGlue_FWW" for the article.  One exception is if you're gluing oily exotics where I still prefer Epoxy - you can dial in your set time, clean up is about the same given the PU glue outflow.  If you have questions or comments, or if you have found this review helpful, please let me know!
historical interactions: ['Gorilla 5000408  Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 4 ounce Bottle, Brown', 'Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 8 ounce Bottle, Brown', 'Uranium Ore']
output:
chain of thought: Okay, so I need to figure out why this user bought the Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, specifically the 2-ounce brown bottle. Let me go through the review and their purchase history to understand their motivations.

First, the user mentions that Gorilla glue is waterproof and a polyurethane. They compared it to other brands like Elmers and PL, saying it's as good but more expensive. That makes me think they're looking for a reliable, durable product without paying the high price. They also note that Gorilla has a better bottle design, which probably makes handling easier and less messy, so they value convenience and mess-free usage.

Then, they talk about how PU glues work—they expand when wet, which means they need to be careful with where they apply them. They recommend using masking tape, so they must be someone who takes their projects seriously and wants precision. They also mention that PU glues have a limited shelf life and that you don't need much, so they might be someone who's budget-conscious, wanting to use what they have without waste.

They also warn about Gorilla glue being toxic to pets, which shows they care about safety beyond just the product. They advise using gloves, wax paper, and towels, indicating they're probably a responsible person who values their pets' health and wants to prevent any potential issues.

Looking at their historical purchases, they've bought 4-ounce and 8-ounce bottles, but they prefer the 2-ounce unless it's a major project. This suggests they might not always need large quantities and prefer smaller, more affordable options when possible. They might be someone who does smaller projects or DIY tasks that don't require huge amounts of glue, making the 2-ounce bottle a cost-effective choice.

They also compared Gorilla to other wood glues like Titebond and found it less strong, so they might be looking for something stronger for their projects, maybe woodworking where they need more durability. But they know it's not as strong as Epoxy for certain materials, so perhaps they're balancing strength with cost or project needs.

Putting it all together, the user seems to be a responsible, cautious individual who values safety, convenience, and cost-effectiveness. item title: Fluke TIS20 9HZ Thermal Infrared Camera with 3 IR-Fusion blending modes, Voice Annotations, Fixed Focus, 120x90 Resolution
review: This "Fluke FLK-TIS20 9HZ Thermal Infrared Camera with 3 IR-Fusion blending modes, Voice Annotations, Fixed Focus, 120x90 Resolution" is a very feature rich and highly useful IR camera. We have several IR cameras that we use for detecting air leaks in our business warehouse. We also have found quite a few other uses, including looking for wildlife in our wooded backyard and helping friends find insulation issues at their houses.  The meter is easy to use and has a fairly intuitive interface. This has three camera modes, including: Normal, IR Only, and (the very useful) IR-Fusion. The IR-Fusion mixes the regular camera image and IR images, which makes it easy to make sense out what you are looking at. I like the ability to save the images to a microSD card (not included) or look at them via the Fluke App (installed easily on my phone). This does take a proprietary battery that actually lasts a very long time.  You will likely find a lot of uses for this very powerful tool and could likely pay for itself by finding insulation problems in you home or business.  Highly Recommended!  CFH

item title: Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 8 ounce Bottle, Brown
review: I have restored many old desks which I acquired from a local University surplus auction.  These oak desks were very good quality, but they unfortunately had an ugly black top on them.  I am unsure of what the black surface is, but it seems to be some sort of plastic/synthetic.  After stripping the desks and removing the edge trim from the tops, I used Gorilla glue to attach furniture grade oak plywood to the black surface.  After making a new edge banding and using traditional finishing techniques, the desks look like a million bucks.  I experimented with other adhesives, but found Gorilla glue to be the absolute best for strength, working time, and cost.  There is a bit of ooze-out when clamping pressure is applied, but I just wait for the glue to dry and scrape the hardened seepage with a chisel befor sanding.  I highly recommend this glue!!!

item title: Verbatim 3D Printer Filament - PLA High-Grade 1.75mm 1kg Reel - Widely Compatible with 3D Printers - Red
review: Summary: Excellent printing material for 3D printers and 3Doodler pens.  This review is for the 1KG 3.0mm PLA filament  I snagged a 3Doodler 2.0 on the recent Kickstarter, but the refills are very pricey - $10-$20 for 25 strands of 10" length.  The 3Doodler does rotate the strand as it feeds, so you will have to cut the strand to a manageable length - I typically do about 16" at a time.  A 1 KG spool is about 160', so this means that a spool gives you as much PLA as 18 packs of the pre-cut strand.  The one downside is that it is all one color, where the prepackaged strand comes in multiple colors.  My sample is of the silver PLA, which comes more as a slightly metallic grey than the more striking silver PLA that 3Doodler provides.  I had purchased a 1/4 kg (~ 1/2 lb) spool of MG Chemicals PLA, but I found it to be more brittle and less consistent with how straight it was, leading to some wastage and difficulties feeding.  This stuff, on the other hand, fed through the 3Doodler as well as the straight strand.  Full size hard plastic spool is solid, vacuum packed with dessicant, no moisture noted during use.  Note: Sample provided for evaluation.

item title: TPI Corporation CE24-DS Direct Drive Exhaust Fan, Shutter Mounted, Single Phase, 24" Diameter, 120 Volt
review: TPI Shutter Mounted Exhaust Fan Model - 20 inches CE-20-DS  TPI Corporation offers three types of direct drive exhaust fans.  Each type comes in the same 8 fan sizes (see Customer Images for a table).  - a guard mounted fan includes a motor & propeller attached to a spiral wire blade guard with an electrical box, pull switch, and rubber mounting bumpers,  - a shutter mounted fan is a combination of two products: a guard mounted fan, and an external shutter.  - a venturi mounted fan is a guard mounted fan on a sheet metal frame, but no shutter.  The outer frame edges are bent toward the inside at 90 degrees for strength.  "Venturi" is a flaring of the sheet metal away from the fan, to direct the air flow.  A venturi mounted fan costs about 25% more than a shutter mounted fan, and it doesn't even include a shutter. The only benefit is the venturi sheet-metal fan-frame.  TPI claims a shutter-mounted fan can be mounted directly to an external wall without you making a frame.  However, that "wall" would have to be quite thin with no studs/building-frame-members in the way.  E.g., a corrugated steel building.  Other than that, you'll have to build a wooden support frame.  Pros:  - excellent air flow.  The sound of all that whooshing air is pretty loud, but any 20" fan moving this much air would be.  There is no mechanical noise.  - has two speeds.  The lower speed moves less air, but is much quieter.  Cons:  - the motor capacitor was "hanging" onto an 8-32 screw on the back of the motor.  It looked like an after-thought; ridiculous even.  I repositioned it, but a customer shouldn't have to modify a product to fix a design/assembly blunder.  See Customer Images.  - the two screws for the plastic cover plate holding the pull chain switch were so over-tightened at the factory, their heads mashed the plate's screw locations.  I re-mounted the switch in a blank metal utility plate.  The ground screw inside the box was so over-tightened by the factory that the threads were stripped, so I had to mount the ground screw elsewhere.  - the five wires exiting the motor have no protection other than the wire's insulation. Motor vibration could eventually wear through that insulation, causing a short.  Other:  - high speed had minimal vibration, but the lower speed shook the entire assembly.  I e-mailed my Amazon receipt to TPI Corporation and requested a new propeller under warranty, which, to their credit, they promptly sent.  The new propeller fixed the problem.  Before the new part arrived, I had fabricated a large support bracket that mostly stabilized the vibrating fan.  With the new [balanced] propeller and the home-made bracket, the fan is quite stable on either speed.  - I was willing to spend more for a better-quality fan with an American made motor, but couldn't find one.  What a shame.  The TPI motor is assembled in Mexico.  This product will replace a Made in the USA General Electric fan that lasted nearly 30 years.  - TPI says the fan must be hard-wired - e.g., using 14/2 NM cable.  Since there is no electrical or safety basis for that "requirement", I clipped the receptacle off a 16 gage extension cord and connected that end into the electrical box.  See Customer Images.  - With extended running, the motor becomes quite hot.  Summary:  This is the only 20" multi-speed all steel fan I could find, which is why I bought it.

(23L)', 'Genie 34107R.S Screw Drive Carriage']

All in all, this is a smart buy that will allow you to fine tune your tools and check precise calibrations without hurting your pocketbook one bit.

item title: Gorilla 5000408  Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 4 ounce Bottle, Brown
review: Review updated 9Aug12  1) Elmers "Ultimate High Performance" is also a Polyurethane (PU) glue and (as far as I can tell) it's as good as Gorilla, but cheaper. also used the PL brand glue and can't tell any notable difference between the three. Have not used Sumo but I understand it sets up faster and as a result apparently has a much more limited shelf life (this is generally not a good thing - see item #3)  2) Gorilla Glue (In my opinion) has thought out their bottle and cap design better than the competition.  While this seems like a minor thing, it really makes a BIG difference in not being messy or wasting glue (See #4)  3) PU glues work differently - they foam up and expand in the presence of moisture and then harden.  This means you will need to think about where the glue comes out and how to keep it from making a mess.  Masking tape is your friend.  4) PU glues have a limited shelf life and you probably don't need as much as you think. Due to the expansion (see #3) you use a LOT less than other types of glue. 4 oz should be MORE than enough for most people, 8 oz is a BIG bottle. I personally buy the 2 oz bottle unless I have a major project.  PU Glues suck moisture out of the air so unless you plan on using it up within a year or two, a LOT is going to go to waste. Don't ask me how I know this.  5) PU Glue is FANTASTIC for lots of things but woodworking glues are still better for woodworking (see #7). They are stronger and you can't clean PU glues up with water the way you can even with the waterproof Titebond products. Also if you use biscuits you will have to moisten them separately to get them to swell.  6) KEEP OUT OF REACH OF CHILDREN AND ANIMALS! Although the glue itself is not toxic and is food safe once cured, it can kill your pets - like antifreeze it apparently tastes good to animals and will swell and harden inside the digestive tract creating a blockage. There is NO antidote and surgery is typically the only solution. There have been MANY cases - just search Google "Dog Gorilla Glue." Wear gloves (rubber or vinyl) and use lots of wax paper and paper towels.  7) Wood glues (Like Titebond II) are still better for wood to wood bonding.  Fine Woodworking did a test (Issue #192) and found Polyurethane glues to be about half as strong in this application.  Search "HowStrongisYourGlue_FWW" for the article.  One exception is if you're gluing oily exotics where I personally still prefer Epoxy - you can dial in your set time, clean up is about the same given the PU glue outflow.  [...]
historical interactions: []
output:
chain of thought: Okay, so I need to figure out why someone bought the Gorilla 500408 glue based on the reviews and historical items provided. Let me start by reading the review carefully.

The review mentions several points. First, the person compared Gorilla Glue to Elmers' Ultimate High Performance and another brand, PL. They found Gorilla as good as the other polyurethane glue but cheaper. That suggests cost-effectiveness is a reason, but they also noted that Sumo glue sets up faster but has a limited shelf life, which isn't great.

Next, the review talks about the bottle design. The Gorilla glue has a better cap design, which helps prevent mess and waste. That's a practical reason for purchasing—keeping things tidy and not wasting glue.

Then, there's a discussion about how PU glues work. They need to be applied in the presence of moisture, which means using masking tape to control where the glue goes. This might be important if the user is doing detailed woodworking or needs precise coverage.

The review also mentions that PU glues have a limited shelf life and that you don't need as much as you think because of the expansion. The user prefers a smaller 2-ounce bottle unless it's a major project, so they're focused on convenience and not wasting glue.

There's a concern about pets. Gorilla Glue can be toxic to animals, so the user is taking precautions by keeping it away from pets and using protective gear. This shows they're health-conscious and cautious about potential risks.

They also compared Gorilla to wood glues like Titebond II, noting that wood glues are stronger and easier to clean up. So, if the user is working with wood, Gorilla might not be their first choice, but for other uses, it's good.

Putting it all together, the main reasons seem to be cost-effectiveness, practical bottle design, ease of use with masking tape, limited waste, and health safety considerations. The user prefers a glue that's efficient, easy to handle, and safe for their projects, especially woodworking and avoiding pet hazards.
answer: The user purchased the Gorilla 500408 glue likely for its cost-effectiveness, practical bottle design, ease of use with masking tape, minimal waste, and health safety, especially for woodworking and pet safety.

item title: SharkNinja Rocket DeluxePro Ultra-Light Upright Corded Stick Vacuum, Bordeaux
review: I bought this unit to replace a $ 1500.00 Electrolux vacuum which does an adequate job but weighs 40-50 lbs and rolls like a tank.  I nor my wife ever liked having to get it out because you ran into everything in the floor trying to vacuum around it. So new day and the monster is gone so to make vacuuming easier and less hassle I chose the Shark Rocket True Pet unit since we have a long hair English Springer Spaniel and he is like the Peanuts character that everywhere he goes he leaves a mess (hair I mean lots of hair).  The vacuum came without incident and as I began to read the description in the booklet sent with the unit I found that two of the items I wanted most was the small motorized brush for furniture and another small non motorized brush for furniture were not in the original implement box.  Both were listed as part of the TruePet system but were not included in the unit sent.  I called Shark and was given excellent service by their personnel.  The two units not included had a retail value of (60 and 20 dollars) respectively.  The customer service staff were cordial and indicated that the both units would be sent out within a week.  Presuming no clichs in shipping I am very happy with the floor care this unit provides and I expect that I will see the same service on the furniture implements.  I can say that the professional and cordial support I received led me to say that Amazon's service has always been 5+ and now it appears that Shark vacuums has the same care and detail in the care of their clients.  Good to know a few companies still feel that customer service is the final detail in a satisfied customer.

item title: WD-40 300281 Specialist Industrial-Strength Degreaser 15 OZ (Pack of 1)
review: Works but spray is too strong and difficult to modulate. The degreaser does not evaporate so you have to wipe it off. I compared it to $3 can of another brand and that cleaner did just as well and evaporated completely.  The cheap competitive cleaner also had a traditional nozzle that was very easy to control the intensity of the spray. This WD-40 degreaser might be very good for some applications but there are cheaper alternatives that in some are much better. I also think it is way overpriced compared to any of the competition, almost $5 higher, too much for just for the advantage of having the straw built-in. I also think most WD-40 products are over-hyped and there are other products just as good and in many cases a lot better. I use a gelling grease that is liquid on application and turns to a grease a short time later. It works much better than WD-40 to lubricate bearings, locks and just about anything that turns or moves. I've also tried WD-40s Rust Penetrant and was not impressed.

item title: RADEX RD1503+ w/o dosimeter: High accuracy Geiger counter, radiation detector (English)
review: Girl testing positive for Radon some years ago comma we had a radon abatement system installed. While this geiger counter does not measure radon per se, it does measure radiation. From what I can tell, after turning the radon abatement system off for a day or two, the background radiation does increase marginally (from 8-10 to 14-16)in the basement so indicates to me that both the radon abatement system, and as geiger counter, are functioning.  I was able to get it to really set off when I laid it on a smoke detector.  Ionizing smoke detectors have a minute amount of radioactive material.  With a little trial and error I was able to get a reading as high as 52, enough that the audio alarm was set off.  Without any type of standard to measure again, I cannot speak to the accuracy of the geiger counter, however it is quite simple to use. One thing I would like to see future models, perhaps, is a lanyard slot for a wrist or neck strap.  I also wish the back light would stay on a little longer. Overall, however, besides a little hesitation on how to install the batteries, I found the geiger counter to be very simple to use.

item title: 3Doodler 2.0 + 2 plastic packs + US plug
review: Summary: Super fun, ideal for ages ~9 and up, though good for as young as ~6-7 with supervision...  I missed out on the Kickstarter for the 3Doodler 1.0, and in hindsight that was a good thing.  From what I can tell, the 3Doodler 2.0 is a much, much improved product.  That said, its still not perfect, and so takes some tuning / getting used to.  I managed to score my 2.0 on Kickstarter this time, and have been playing with it nonstop for over a week.  It does take some getting used to - the first ~2 strands I used didn't amount to anything, but I've just finished a cool mechanical sculpture.  >>>Starting up the pen First of all, you have to realize that the feed mechanism has a long lead-in.  This means that from when the pen grabs the strand to when you start to get extruded melt takes time  like a good minute or so.  Take a look at where the strand is feeding into the pen, and if you can see it moving in, continue waiting.  Only if it appears stalled should you start to rotate the strand (gently) clockwise.  >>>Shutting down the pen If Im planning to start back up with the same strand, I will back the strand up 10 blinks, then unplug.  ODepending on what I plan to do, I will either remove the strand  >>>Adjusting the pen temperature For now I am finding it easier to work in 2D, then assemble the pieces into 3D.  This means its easier to work with a higher temp  about half a rotation on the adjustment screw.  If I want to extrude a thread which stands, I blow on it gently as it comes out to cool it faster.  As I get better, I will likely turn the temp back down.  One plus of the higher temp is better welding and faster feed, though there might be a higher risk of jamming.  >>>Jamming My theory on the distance between the feed gears and the melt chamber is that if the strand gets soft in the feed gears, it jams.  Note that the instructions indicate that you may need to let the 3Doodler rest from time to time.  I suspect that this is because the pen gets too warm - my observation is that this tends to happen more when you let the pen sit.  If you keep drawing and feeding more strand in, it doesn't have time to get hot inside the feed gears .  If the pen stops feeding while you're using it, give it a good few seconds, then back the strand out (press fast and slow feed simultaneously) then clip off the melted portion and start feeding again.  >>>ABS vs PLA They are not kidding about ventilation, though its much more with the ABS.  I ran about 3-4 strands through in the kitchen, which has decent airflow, but I got a bit of a headache from the smell.  Will set up a small fan nearby next time.  PLA on the other hand in our kitchen was no problem.  ABS does better standing structures though as it cools faster due to the higher melt temp.  >>>Coil stock I bought a ~1 lb spool of 3 mm PLA - it works perfectly except that you do have to straighten it out a little before you use it.  As the strand does rotate as it feeds, you need to also cut it to a managable length.  I've been cutting mine to perhaps 15" then manually unbending it a little.  This also softens up the PLA so its not as rigid.  I cut off a bunch at a time and re-vacuum seal the spool so it doesn't absorb moisture.  >>>Tips: 1) Use a fine tip sharpie to mark the strand when you're feeding - that way you can tell if it's moving or not 2) Get yourself a set of small diagonal cutters - much easier to snip the strand 3) Toss the larger silicone heat cover - it's useless and just gets in the way 4) Double press the slow feed to start up a new strand and go read a book.  Seriously though, it takes a lot longer than you think it should. 5) Get a clear flexible piece of plastic - I use a 5 mil empty laminating pouch.  I can then draw a pattern with pencil on paper, then use the 3Doodler to draw on the plastic - it sticks enough that you can work, then it pops off cleanly when finished. 6) Get a small fan to keep the area ventilated, and also to cool your projects as you are working on them 7) If you 3Doodler sketch is warped or bent, draw on it with some new material - this typically heats the part up enough that you can bend it a little, then hold it until it cools 8) Don't be afraid to incorporate other materials in your sketches - PLA in particular sticks very well to paper, toothpicks, wood blocks, etc.  If you have questions, comments, or found this review helpful, please let me know!

item title: Gorilla Original Gorilla Glue, Waterproof Polyurethane Glue, 8 ounce Bottle, Brown
review: "Gorilla Glue" has become one of the most used "tools" in our house. We have used it to repair wooden chairs, fix a wooden medicine chest, glue soles back on to sneekers, fill cracks in a wall, and at least half a dozen other fixes in the past month.  Here are my observations:  * You must read the directions! * Surface needs to be damp for the glue to work * Use clamps when possible * It expands a *LOT*, use with caution or you might accidently glue your project to the table as it expands overnight! This happend to me :-) * This is strong glue and hard to get off once it is on a surface  Highly recommended!

review: First of all (if the picture on Amazon has not been corrected yet), this is six rolls of 2 inch wide 10 yards long tape, not a big rectangular sheet.  This came just at the right time when my 9-year old kid just visited the Spy Museum in Washington DC and at the same time practicing fingerprint lifting in their science subject at school using talc powder and mommy's facial brush. We used baby powder and soot created by a candle on the bottom of a steel cup as opposed to the real black or bi-chromatic powder. Tried on a mirror surface and counter top.  Overall, a very educational experience for my kid.

input: item title: Jaybird And Mais 6000 Jayco Co-Adhesive Grip Tape: 1-1/2 In. X 15 Ft. review: This Jayco grip tape is good quality and generally works well on most surfaces. We have used this on wooden tool handles and on polypropylene handles (Cold Steel Indian War Club with Polypropylene and Cold Steel Gladius Trainer) with good success. The tape goes on easily and is self adhesive. The grip surface is very good, but it is a little tacky to the touch and it did rip after very heavy use.
